problems.title: MSA 1.1 Using Walking Rates to Explore Linear Relationships

text: In the Variables and Patterns unit, we investigated a bicycle touring business. We used contextual situations, tables, graphs, and equations to represent patterns relating variables such as cost, income, and profit. We looked at some linear relationships, like the relationship between cost and number of rental bikes represented in this graph.

tiles.title: Adrian's Weekly Rental Rates for Bikes

text: A relationship between two variables for which all points lie on a straight line is called a linear relationship. The graph of Adrian’s Rental Rates is an example of a linear relationship.
How can we recognize a linear relationship in a context, table, or graph?

Ms. Chang’s class decides to participate in a walkathon. Each participant must find sponsors to pledge a certain amount of money for each kilometer the participant walks. Leanne suggests that they determine their walking rates in meters per second, so they can make predictions about the number of meters walked and amount of money raised. She collects some meter sticks and her cell phone to use as a timer for her walking experiment.
What do you think your walking rate is?

• Measuring device, such as, meter stick or string
  • Timer that can count seconds
  • Paper and pencil or other materials to record your results

• Measure the distance you are going to walk, such as 10 meters
  • Have one person walk the distance at their normal pace
  • Keep track of how many seconds it takes the walker
  • Record the walking rate
  • Repeat for each person in the group
• Make a prediction about your walking rate.

Students will discuss if they are “slow walkers” or “fast walkers”. They typically have no experience measuring their walking rates. Some students may have experience with fitness trackers that measure steps per day.
• Use a meter stick and timer to find your walking rate. What is your walking rate in meters per second?

It will be easier for students to find their walking rates by seeing how far they walk in, for example, 5 or 10 seconds and then divide the number of meters they walked by the number of seconds for which they walked.
Situation A. Walking at a Consistent Rate
Assume you continue to walk at the rate determined in the Initial Challenge
Answers will vary depending on the student’s walking rate. Sample answers are provided for a walking rate of 2 meters per second, and for a student who walks r meters per second.
• How long would it take you to walk 500 meters?
A student who walks 2 meters per second will walk 500 meters in 250 seconds, or 4 minutes and 10 seconds.
A student who walks r meters per second will walk 500 meters in 500/r seconds.
• How far could you walk in 5 seconds, 10 seconds, 30 seconds? In 60 seconds? In 1 hour?
A student who walks 2 meters per second will walk 10 meters in 5 seconds, 20 meters in 10 seconds, 60 meters in 30 seconds, 120 meters in 60 seconds, and 7200 meters in 1 hour.
A student who walks r meters per second will walk 5r meters in 5 seconds, 10r meters in 10 seconds, 30r meters in 30 seconds, 60r meters in 60 seconds, and 3600r meters in 1 hour.
• Write an equation that represents the distance d in meters that you could walk in t seconds. Compare your equation to your classmates’ equations.
For a walking rate of 2 meters per second, an equation is d=2t, where d is the distance in meters and t is the time in seconds.
For a walking rate of r meters per second, an equation is d = rt, where d is the distance in meters and t is the time in seconds.
• Describe what a graph of your equation would look like. Check your answer by making a graph of your data.
For a walking rate of 2 meters per second: The graph would be a line starting at (0,0). For every one second walked, the distance increases by 2.
For a walking rate of r meters per second: The graph would be a line starting at (0,0). For every one second walked, the distance increases by r.
Examine Liz’s strategy. Is she correct? Explain.
I think walking rates are like ratios. So, I used proportional reasoning to write 'for every' statements to answer the questions in Situation A.

Sample answer: She is correct. The ratio of meters walked to seconds always stays the same, so, for example, (1.5 meters)/(1 second) = (7.5 meters)/(5 seconds) = (15 meters)/(10 seconds). So you can always predict how long it will take to walk a specific distance based on this constant ratio.
Describe how the distance you walk at a constant rate of time is represented in an equation and graph.
Student answers will vary based on their walking rates.
In general, for a walking rate of r meters per second, you can walk a distance in meters that is r times the number of seconds. d= rt
With the graph, for every increase of 1 second, the distance will increase by the walking rate. This will be an increasing graph that begins at the origin (0,0)

Did you know race walking is an Olympic event? There are rules to ensure that participants are walking and not running. One foot must always be touching the ground and on each stride the advancing leg must remain straight until the athlete passes over it. In the Tokyo 2021 Olympics there were three events - the men’s 20 km, the women’s 20 km, and the men’s 50 km. The 2021 Tokyo Olympics may be the last year that the 50 km men’s race is held, however it may be replaced with a mixed gender event. At the 2021 Tokyo games the men’s 20 km gold medalist was Massimo Stano of Italy who finished in 1 hour 21 minutes and 5 seconds which puts his average pace at about 9.2 miles per hour. The 20 km women’s gold medalist was Antonella Palmisano of Italy who finished in 1 hour 29 minutes and 12 seconds which puts her pace at about 8.4 miles per hour.

This Problem introduces patterns of change between two variables in the context of a walkathon. In the Initial Challenge students determine their walking rates in meters per second as a ratio of distance to time. In the What If Situations students will answer questions about time and distance using their constant walking rates and write an equation that models the distance walked over time at their constant walking rates.
Describe how the distance you walk at a constant rate of time is represented in an equation and graph.
Ask students to describe if they are fast or slow walkers and to describe their evidence.

• In the Grade 6 Comparing Quantities Unit you looked at a problem about a walking backwards race. The average middle school student walks backwards ¼ of a mile in 6 minutes. What does this rate mean?
  • Who is the slowest walker you know? Who is the fastest walker you know?
  • What do you think your walking rate is in miles per hour? In meters per second?

Tell a story about walkathons. Students may have some experience with other “–athons.” Discuss the walkathon described in the Student Edition and that Ms. Chang’s class suggests finding their walking rates. Now tell students that they will have a chance to check their guesses about their walking rates.
Describe the experiment. Students should do the experiment twice to get a more accurate walking rate.

• What does meters per second mean?
  • How might meter sticks and a timer help?
  • What are the variables?
  • What is the relationship between the variables?
Allow students to problem solve how to find their walking rates.

• What are the variables that we need to collect data on?
  • How can we measure those?
  • If someone is walking, what do we need to measure to find the walking rate?
  • How long would you need to walk for someone to get an idea of how fast or slow you walk?
  • What is a convenient distance to use?

Look to see how students are recording their walking rates. Example: Some may use unit rates, such as 2.5 meters per second, and some may use ratios, such as 2.5 m/1 sec. Some students will scale their results differently. There are two unit rates.

As you are circulating during the Explore, listen to the way students are using their walking rate. Are they using “for every” language; are they looking at scaling them up or down to fit the situation; are they seeing this constant rate in the graph; are they using a unit rate in an equation? Find examples from student work to use in the Summary.
Ask for some of the students’ walking rates. Most students will cluster around 2 to 2.5 meters per second. Use one or two of the more typical walking rates to answer the questions in the Problem.

• What information does the rate tell you?
  • When might you use this rate rather than meters per second?

• How do you find how long it takes to walk a given distance, in particular, asking about 500 meters in situation A?
  • How do you find how far you can walk in a given time? Use the examples from What If Situation A for students to demonstrate their thinking.
  • How does the equation show the relationship between the two variables?
  • Explain what information the numbers and variables in your equation represent.
  • Which variable in your equation is the independent variable, and which is the dependent variable?
As you finish the mathematical discussions, have students reflect on the Now What Do You Know question(s).

problems.title: MSA 1.2 Walking Rates
problems.subtitle: Exploring Linear Relationships with Tables, Graphs, and Equations

text: Problem 1.2 Walking Rates: Exploring Linear Relationships with Tables, Graphs, and Equations

In earlier units we explored relationships which were linear and proportional. For example, we graphed the relationship between cost and number of bikes rented in Variables and Patterns. We also explored the relationship between time and distance walking backwards in Comparing Quantities. In Comparing and Scaling, we learned to recognize the difference between proportional and non-proportional relationships when we investigated pizza prices.
Malcom determined that his walking rate was 1.5 meters per second. For every 1 second he walks, his distance increases by 1.5 meters. This information can be represented in expressions and equations.
is an expression that represents the distance walked every second.
can is also be an expression for the distance that he walked every second.
the equation shows the equivalence of two expressions (d and 1.5t)
The equation also represents the relationship between the two variables, d and t
The expressions d and 1.5t are equivalent expressions. They both represent the distance that Malcom walks at 1.5 meters per second

Think about the effect a walking rate has on the relationship between time walked and distance walked. This will provide some important clues about how to identify linear relationships from tables, graphs, expressions, and equations.
Alana, Gilberto, and Leanne were students in Ms. Chang’s class. They each did the walking experiment to find their walking rate.

content.name: Walking Rates for Ms. Chang's Class

text: They had some questions about how their walking data is represented in a table, graph, or equation.
• Make a table showing the distance walked by each student for the first ten seconds.
• Graph the times and distances on the same coordinate axes. Use a different color for each student.
• Write an equation that represents the relationship between the time t and distance d walked by each student.
Alana: d = t or d = 1t; Gilberto: d = 2t; Leanne: d = 2.5t.
• How are the walking rates represented in the different representations?
In the equation the walking rate is represented as the number that you multiply by the time to get distance. (Note that students will learn later that the multiplier is called the coefficient.)

In the table, the walking rate is represented as the difference between values for distance in consecutive rows (1 second apart). So, as the x-values increase by 1, the y values will increase by the walking rate. (Note that students will learn later that this is called the rate of change.)

In the graph, the walking rate is represented as the steepness of the graph – the greater the walking rate, the steeper the line on the graph. (Note that students will learn later that this is called the slope.)
• What are the advantages and disadvantages of each representation? Explain.
The table is the most helpful because I can figure out the pattern, but I can also see many values that would answer questions.

The graph is the most important because I can see the pattern for the walking rates. I can also see how the pattern of change for one line is related to the pattern of change for another. I can also find or approximate answers to questions.
The equation is the most useful because I can use any amount of time to find the distance, not just small values for time like on a graph or table.
For each of Yvonne's questions what answer would you give her?
How can I tell from the table that the relationships between time and distance are proportional?
The relationships are proportional. On the table, you can take any two coordinate pairs and write a proportion. For example on the table for Gilberto:

Also, you can see this because any distance divided by time gives a constant ratio. Since the relationship is proportional, it is also linear because distance divided by time gives a constant rate of change.
(Note: Not all linear relationships are proportional.)
How can I use a table or graph to answer the question:
For each student, if time t increases by 1 second, by how much does the distance change?

If time increases by 1 second, she can find the change in distance on a graph by looking at the steepness of the line. Or, how much the y-variable changes (goes up or down) for every change of 1 in the x-variable.
If time increases by 1 second, she can find the change in distance on a table by looking at the distance in two consecutive rows (one second apart) and calculating the difference.
Situation B. Valentina and Omar have the Same Walking Rate
Valentina and Omar have the same walking rate. Each made a graph to represent their data.
Yes. They used different scales, so the graphs look different.

Valentina and Omar’s graphs are similar in that, when the points are connected, the graphs have the same rate of change and y-intercept. Omar graphed his walking rate for 40 seconds, whereas Valentina graphed his walking rate for 4 seconds. Omar uses intervals of 5 seconds and 10 meters, whereas Valentina uses intervals of 1 second and 1 meter. The different scales makes it appear that Valentina has a faster walking rate. However, their walking rates are the same. Because Omar’s vertical scale has twice the value as the horizontal scale, it appears to “pull down” the points as you have less vertical “movement” for every point. Valentina’s scales both have a value of one for every grid line. So, you will have the “same” movement on the horizontal and vertical axes for each coordinate pair.
• Which expression below could represent the distance of Omar? Valentine?
The expression 2t could represent both of their distances. On both graphs, the distance traveled is always twice the time in seconds, so they are traveling 2 meters every second.
Five other friends made the following representations of their Walkathon data. Could any of these relationships be linear relationships? Explain.
Elizabeth and Billie’s relationships are linear and proportional.

Elizabeth walks at a constant rate of 3 meters every 2 seconds, which you can see in the table. Billie walks at a constant rate of 2.25 m/s, since the equation is in the form of d = rt, similar to the equations for Alana, Gilberto, and Leanne. Both of these relationships are also proportional, since at 0 seconds they have walked 0 meters.

George’s, Evo’s, and Bob’s relationships are not linear. The table for George does not show a constant rate of change. Evo’s graph does not make a straight line, so it does not show a constant rate of change. In the equation for Bob, the rate is a variable, so the walking rate is not constant. (Some students may make graphs and claim the relationships are either linear or not based on whether the data lie on a straight line.)
How can you recognize a linear pattern of change in a verbal context, table, a graph, expression, or an equation?

• Main idea: Relationships are linear when there is a constant rate of change.
  • Verbal context: key words include “constant,” “[increase/decrease] by the same amount every [year/second/month]”
  • Table: The values of one variable change at a constant rate when the other variable changes at a constant rate.
  • Graph: The graph is a straight line.
  • Expression: The independent variable is multiplied by a constant.
  • Equation: The independent variable is multiplied by a constant, so the dependent variable will change at a constant rate.
Problem 1.2 Walking Rates: Exploring Linear Relationships with Tables, Graphs, and Equations

Students explore the walking rates of three students. In the Initial Challenge they will make a table, graph, and equation to represent the walking rates of these students over time. In What If Situation A students will review what it means to be proportional and describe rate of change. What If Situations B and C will look at different representations and require students to determine if they are representing linear contexts.
How can you recognize a linear pattern of change in a verbal context, a table, a graph, an expression, or an equation?
The introduction to this Problem offers a chance to revisit the vocabulary while also introducing “equivalent expressions” and “rate of change.”
Introduce the three students, Alana, Gilberto, and Leanne and their walking rates. Let students know that they will be analyzing the progress of the three students.
• Make a conjecture. If you increased your walking rate, how would it change your equation, graph, and table?
Students should each make their own tables and graphs, but they can discuss the questions in pairs. This will give you an opportunity to examine students’ abilities to make tables and graphs.

• What are the two variables in the relationship?
  • Why do you think there are four columns in the table?
  • Which axis should represent time? Which should represent distance? Explain.
Students may not see how the walking rate is represented in the table or graph. This conversation may be something that you leave students thinking about until the Summary.

Select student work to use in the Summary. Select tables that show the rate of change for each student (if there is a student who didn’t have the time increase by one, use that also). Select graphs that may have different scales to show how this changes the look of the graph but not the rate of change. Select equations from students to emphasize the rate of change and how it appears in the equation.

• Who walks the fastest? Who walks the slowest? How can you tell?
  • If my walking rate was 2.3 meters per second, where would the line of my data be on the graph?
  • What is the equation for Alana? Gilberto? Leanne? How did you find it?
  • If you increased your walking rate, what effect would that have on your table or graph?
As you change your walking rate to a faster rate, what effect does this have on the original equation?
During this portion of the Summary, you will want to focus on using the representations (verbal context, table, graph, expression, equation) to help students understand how to answer these questions:

• Is the relationship linear?
  • If so, what is the rate of change?
  • Is the relationship proportional?
  • If so, what is the constant of proportionality?
  • Will the rate of change and the constant of proportionality always be the same?
You may want to make anchor charts that can be used to display the representations.

• Is the relationship between the variables (time walked and distance) linear?
  • How does the walking rate/rate of change show up in the different representations?
As you finish the mathematical discussions, have students reflect on the Now What Do You Know question(s).

problems.title: MSA 1.3 Raising Money
problems.subtitle: Using Linear Relationships to Solve Problems

text: In Problems 1.1 and 1.2, the distance walked depended on the time. This tells us that distance is the dependent variable and time is the independent variable. In this Problem, we will look at relationships between two other variables in a walkathon.

The students in Ms. Chang’s class are trying to estimate how much money they might raise for charity by doing a walkathon. Each participant in the walkathon must find sponsers to pledge a certain amount of money for each kilometer he or she walks. The class refers to these as pledge plans.

Several questions come up in their discussions:

  • What variables can affect the amount of money that is collected?
  • How can we use these variables to estimate the amount of money each student will collect?
  • Will the amount of money collected be the same for each walker?
Each student found sponsors who pledge to donate money according to the following descriptions.

columns.name: Pledge Plan
values: $10 regardless of how far she walks

text: • Who will raise the most money? Explain.
The answer depends on how long the walkathon is.
Leanne will raise the most money if the walkathon is shorter than 5 kilometers; Gilberto will “catch up” to Leanne when he walks 5 kilometers because he raises $2 per kilometer.
Gilberto will raise the most money if the walkathon is longer than 5 kilometers.
Alana will never raise the most money because she has a smaller starting donation than Leanne and a smaller per-kilometer-walked donation than Gilberto.
• Explain why the relationship between dollars and kilometers represents a linear relationship?

They are linear relationships because the students all raise a constant rate of money for each kilometer walked. Leanne raises $0 per kilometer, Gilberto raises $2 per kilometer, and Alana raises $0.50 per kilometer. This will form a straight line as each increase in 1 km leads to a constant increase in the donation monies.
Situation A. Using Representations to Solve Problems
• In Alana’s plan, how is the fixed $5 donation represented in a table? A graph? An equation?

The fixed $5 donation represents the amount of money she raises by walking 0 kilometers. In the table, it is the amount of the donation when the distance is 0. (0,5) is the point where Alana’s graph intersects the y-axis; it is the point on the line for her plan with an x-coordinate of 0. In the equation, 5 is the term that is added to 0.50d where d represents the distance walked.
On Alana's line, the fixed donation is represented by the y-intercept of (0,5).
m = 5 + 0.50d where 5 is the fixed donation amount added into the equation.
• For each plan, how is the rate of change shown in the table, graph, and equation?

The rate of change for Alana is $0.50 per kilometer. In the table, this is shown by the amount that the donation increases for every 1 kilometer or the amount each row of the y-variable increases for every increase of 1 km. The graph shows the rate of change as how much the line rises for every kilometer. In the equation, we see the rate of change in the coefficient, or the amount that is multiplied by the x-variable.

tiles.title: Alana's rate of change in a table
Pledges Graph showing 0.5 rise per 1 unit

text: m = 5 + 0.50d where 0.50 is the rate of change multiplier or coefficient of the variable.
• On which graph does the point (12, 11) lie? What information does this point represent?
The point (12,11) lies on Alana’s graph since $5 + $0.50 x 12 = $5 + $6 = $11. This point means that if Alana walks 12 kilometers, each sponsor will donate $11.
• On which table can you find the entry (5,10)?
Both, Gilberto, and Leanne They both will collect $10 if they walk 5 km.
• Which equation has the point (4,8) as a solution?
• Suppose each student walks 8 kilometers in the walkathon. How much money does each sponsor donate? Explain how you found your answer.
Leanne: Each sponsor donates $10 because they donate $10 regardless of how far she walks.
Gilberto: Each sponsor donates $2 • 8 = $16 because they donate $2 per kilometer he walks.
Alana: Each sponsor donates $5 + $0.50 • 8 = $5 + $4 = $9 because they donate $5 plus $0.50 per kilometer she walks.
• Suppose each student raises $10 from a sponsor. How many kilometers does each student walk? Explain.
Leanne: We cannot determine how far she walks since the amount of money she raises does not depend on how many kilometers she walks.
Alana: 10 kilometers because $10 - $5 = $5 so she has to raise $5 by walking; since she raises $0.50 per kilometer walked, she must walk $5 / $0.50 = 10 kilometers.
The relationships for Alana, Gilberto, and Leanne pledge plans are linear and proportional.
Leanne’s, Gilberto’s, and Alana’s plans are linear because they all show a constant rate of money raised per kilometer walked.

Only Gilberto’s pledge plan is proportional because his plan doesn’t involve raising any money without walking any kilometers. The graph goes through the origin. And values from the table can be made into proportions.
Gilberto decides to give a T-shirt to each of his sponsors. Each shirt costs him $4.75. He plans to pay for each shirt with some of the money he raises from each sponsor.
• Write an expression that represents the amount of money Gilberto raises after paying for the T-shirts?

For each sponsor, Gilberto will earn $2 per kilometer walked and pay $4.75 regardless of how far he walks. The expression that represents the amount of money Gilberto will raise with this plan is 2*d – 4.75, where d represents the distance walked.
• How does this additional cost affect the amount of money he has raised reflected in a table? Graph? Equation?

When he has walked 0 km, he will have earned –$4.75, so (0, –4.75) will be a value on the table. After that, for each kilometer he walks, the money he raises will increase by $2. So (1, –2.75) will be the next value on the table. For each kilometer, the money raises will be $4.75 less than it was before.
The whole line ‘slides down’. Instead of the y-axis being at the origin, the line will intersect the y-axis at (0, –4.75). For each kilometer, the money raises will be $4.75 less than it was before.
We subtract –$4.75 to represent this extra cost, so his profits are always decreased by $4.75, no matter how many kilometers he walks.
How can you predict where the graph of a linear relationship intersects the y-axis from a context, table, or equation that represent the relationship?
The y-intercept is the starting amount when the independent variable is 0.
It might be some set cost, a fee, or some other amount added in or subtracted at the beginning.
On a table, when the independent variable is 0, the y-intercept will be the value of the dependent variable.
If the equation is of the form y = ax + b, the b value is where the line crosses the y-axis.
What are the advantages of using a table, graph, or eqation to solve a problem?

Table: Sometimes the answer is right there. You look for the variable value that you know to find the other variable value that will answer the question.

Sometimes it is easy to use the pattern to find values not on the table. You can extend the table or find "in between" values on the table.

Graph: The graph makes it easy to see the patterns of change.

So to answer a question, you can find the point on the graph that answers the question. If you know the x-value, you can

  1. follow the x-axis to that amount
  2. see where that value "hits the line"
  3. find the y-value of that point

Sometimes you cannot tell the exact amount of a point so you have to estimate.

Equation: You can substitute the value that you know into the equation. Use the equation to find the unknown value.

Sometimes you have to use guess and check to find the value of the variable you do not know.

In the Initial Challenge students are introduced to a new context involving collecting money from sponsors for the walkathon. This context will help students compare and contrast proportion to non-proportional linear relationships. In the What If Situations students will explore how this is shown in descriptions, tables, graphs, and equations. Students will informally explore the y-intercept.
How can you predict where the graph of a linear relationship intersects the y-axis from a context , table, or equation that represent the relationship?

Students first learned the terms “independent variable” and “dependent variable” in Grade 6 Variables and Patterns. If you have not used the terms in this Unit, reintroduce students to the vocabulary of independent variable and dependent variable in the Introduction of Problem 1.3.
Pick one of the previous examples to review dependent variables and independent variables.
Many schools have walkathons or something similar to raise funds for charity. Ask students how they determined what to charge their patrons.

• What variables can affect the amount of money that a student raises?
  • How can you use these variables to estimate the amount of money each student will collect?
  • Will the amount of money raised be the same for each walker? Explain.  
  • Which variable is the independent variable? Which is the dependent variable?
Display the three pledge plans of Leanne, Alana, and Gilberto. How might you decide who is going to raise the most money?

• Who starts out making the most?
  • Will this person always make the most? How much would each person raise if they walked 20 kilometers?
  • When did it change?
  • At what distance does Leanne raise less than Gilberto? Less than Alana?

As you are circulating during the Explore, select examples of student work where students are indicating the y-intercept on a table that includes the y-value when the x-value is zero; in an equation when it is what is “added on” (the b in y = ax +b); or in the context where it is described as the “starting amount.”

You may want to make anchor charts that can be used to display the representations. You can work with students to make the charts, then mark them up to display the big ideas in the Problem, such as showing the rate of change in the table, graph, and equation.

In Comparing and Scaling, students observed that the rate tables relating cost of pizza to number of pizzas worked differently if a constant delivery charge was added. They noticed that there is a constant of proportionality (unit rate) when there is no delivery charge, but not a constant of proportionality (no unit rate) when there is a delivery charge. Here, students are learning about the specific details of linear relationships, in particular when they are proportional or not proportional and the role of the y-intercept.

• How are the tables, graphs, and equations for the pledge plans different from the walking rate representations?
  • Are the relationships between the distance walked and the money earned in pledges all linear? How do you know?
  • How is the rate of change represented in a context? Table? Graph? Equation?
  • How can we tell by looking at the context if the relationship is proportional? Table? Graph? Equation?
As you finish the mathematical discussions, have students reflect on the Now What Do You Know question(s).

We have noticed that, as the independent variable changes by a constant amount, there is a constant pattern of change in the dependent variable. In the last Problem, the graph representing Alana’s pledge plan crossed the y-axis at point at (0, 5). Leanne’s crosses the y-axis at point at (0, 10). Gilberto’s pledge plan crossed the y-axis at (0, 0). These points are called the y-intercepts. The y-intercept is the point where the line crosses the y-axis, or when x = 0.
In this Problem we will continue to explore linear relationships in new contexts.
What information does the y-intercept represent?
How might it be useful in solving problems?
Ms. Chang and Mr. Mamer’s classes decide to use their walkathon money for charity. They put their money in a bank account and withdraw a fixed amount each week.
Ms. Chang’s class provides books to the children’s ward at the hospital each week.
To keep track of the money, Isabella makes a table of the amount of money in the account at the end of each week.

columns.name: Amount of Money at the End of Each Week ($)

text: Mr. Mamer’s class buys games and puzzles for the children’s ward. Keenan uses a graph to keep track of the amount of money in the account at the end of each week.

tiles.title: Money in Mr. Mamer's Class Account

text: • What is the pattern of change for the relationship between the variables? Explain how you know.

The pattern of change for Ms. Chang’s class is a decrease by a consistent amount of $12 each week. Or, for every weeks the account decreases by $12. The pattern of change for Mr. Mamer’s class is a decrease of $100 for every 10 weeks or $10 a week. Or, for every week the account decreases $10.
• How is this pattern the same as those in previous problems? How is it different?
Same: There is a consistent pattern. As the weeks increase, there is a consistent change in the amount of money.
Different: As the weeks increase, the amount of money decreases. The previous patterns were increasing.
Both appear to be linear. Neither relationship is proportional.
Looking at a proportion from the table of values (or 2 points on the graph).
This means that the y-intercept is not 0. So, ratios of the variables will not be related by a multiplicative relationship. There will also be an additive relationship between the variables.
Looking at a proportion from 2 points on the graph (or the table of values).
This means that the y-intercept is not 0. So, ratios of the variables will not be related by a multiplicative relationship. There will also be an additive relationship between the variables.
Situation A. Using the Data to Answer Questions
• How much money is in the account at the start? Explain.
Ms. Chang: $144 because this is the amount of money in the account for week 0, or the start of keeping track of the money.
Mr. Mamer: $500 because this is the amount of money in the account for week 0, or the start of keeping track of the money.
• How much money is withdrawn each week?
• Write an equation that represents the relationship. Explain what information each number and variable represent.

Ms. Chang: A = 144 + –12n or 144 – 12n, where n represents the number of weeks and A represents the amount of money in the account after n weeks. The rate at which the amount of money in the account is changing is –$12 per week, and the starting amount of money in the club’s account is $144.

Mr. Mamer: A = 500 + –10n or 500 – 10n, where n represents the number of weeks and A represents the amount of money in the account after n weeks. The rate at which the amount of money in the account is changing is –$10 per week, and the starting amount of money in the club’s account is $500.
• After 10 weeks, how much money was used to buy items for the children’s ward at the hospital? How much money was left? Explain how you found the answer.

Ms. Chang: The rate at which the amount of money in the account is changing is -$12 per week, so after 10 weeks the club has donated $12(10) = $120. Since they started with $144, they now have $144-$120=$24 left in the account.

Mr. Mamer: The rate at which the amount of money in the account is changing is -$10 per week, so after 10 weeks the club has donated $10(10) = $100. Since they started with $500, they now have $500-$100=$400 left in the account.
• At what week will all the money be spent? Where is this point on the graph?
Ms. Chang: If they spent $12 per week and they had $144 at the beginning, then all the money would be spent after 144/12 = 12 weeks.

Mr. Mamer: If they spent $10 per week and they had $500 at the beginning, then all the money would be spent after 500/10 = 50 weeks. This is the point where the graph crosses the horizontal axis, since that represents A=0.
One of Mr. Mamer’s students wrote the following two statements to help her answer questions about their account. What questions was she trying to answer?

The first equation is setting the expression for how much money is left in the account after t weeks equal to 100, so she is trying to find how many weeks it will take for there to be $100 left in the account. The second equation is trying to find how many weeks it will take for there to be less than $100 left in the account.
If a relationship is linear, how can you tell if the pattern of change is decreasing, increasing, oe neither?
Both of the relationships in this Problem have decreasing rates of changes.
The equation will be in the form of some initial amount then subtracting the constant for every increase in the independent variable. There will be a negative coefficient.
As the independent variable increases, the dependent variable decreases.
The graph of the line will decrease (fall) from left to right.
Problem 1.4 Walkathon Money: Expressing Linear Relationships and Proportionality

This Problem introduces negative rates of change (negative slope). The Initial Challenge poses two situations involving a decreasing linear relationship. One situation uses a graphical representation and the other uses a tabular representation. In the What If Situations students will use these representations to answer questions.
If a relationship is linear, how can you tell if the pattern of change is decreasing, increasing, or neither?
If you did not introduce the vocabulary term “y-intercept” in the Summary of Problem 1.3, the Introduction of this Problem offers the opportunity.
Tell students that they have been looking at linear relationships and determining whether the relationships are proportional.

• How can you tell whether a relationship is linear?
  • Are all linear relationships proportional?
Tell the first story of how one class is going to use the money they raised from the walkathon.

• What do you notice and what do you wonder?
  • Do you have any “What If…” questions?
  • Would the graph of these data look like the pledge plan data?
  • Is this a linear relationship?
This is the first time that students have encountered negative rates of change or negative slope. You can ask students why the line slants down or is decreasing from left to right.

• How can you represent Ms. Chang’s class data in a graph?
  • How can you represent Mr. Mamer’s class data in a table?

Listen during the Explore for how students are describing what is happening with the money in the class accounts. Are they noticing on a table that as the number of weeks is increasing, the amount of money is decreasing at a constant rate; on a graph the line is decreasing (fall) from left to right; and in an equation the coefficient is negative. Listen for how students contrast these representations to those in previous problems. Use their conversations to lead the Summary.

• Do the classes have the same thing happening in their bank accounts?
  • What do you notice about the amount in the accounts for the two classes?
You may begin by asking a few questions about solutions when an amount is given in order to have students analyze specific instances in the relationship.

• What If Situation A asks about the amount of money at 10 weeks. We know the value of the x variable (independent variable). How do we find the value of the other variable?
  • What If Situation A asks about when the money is spent. Where would we see this in the table?
  • Where would we see this on the graph?
  • In What if Situation B, what questions might the student have about the accounts?
This Problem is a chance to make sense of decreasing linear relationships.

• For each class, how much money is being spent or withdrawn each week?
  • Compare the rates of change in this Problem with other rates that we have studied in this Unit. How do the rates in this Problem show up in a table? In a graph? In an equation?
  • What are the y-intercepts?
  • What do they tell you about the money in each class’s account?
  • What is the pattern of change for the relationship between the variables?

investigations.title: MSA Investigation 2 Using Tables, Graphs, and Equations to Solve Problems

problems.title: MSA 2.1 Henri and Emile’s Race
problems.subtitle: Developing Strategies to Find a Solution

text: In the last Investigation, we examined linear relationships. For example, the distance, d, a person walks at a rate depends on the amount of time, t, the person walks. Also, the amount of money, A, a person raises from each sponsor depends on the distance, d, walked in the walkathon. Both of these relationships are linear. You might have written the following equations to represent these two relationships for Alana.
Distance d, Alana walks at 1 meter per second for t seconds
The amount of money A that Alana collects for walking d meters
We used tables and graphs to represent these relationships. These representations are useful in answering questions about linear relationships. For example,
If we know something about distance d, how can we find the corresponding value of A?
If we know something about A, how can we find the corresponding value of d?
In this Investigation, we will continue to solve problems involving walking rates and other linear relationships using tables, graphs, and equations.
Problem 2.1 Henri and Emile's Race: Developing Strategies to Find a Solution

In Ms. Chang’s class, Emile found out that his walking rate is 2.5 meters per second. That is, Emile walks 2.5 meters for every 1 second. When he gets home from school, he helps his younger brother Henri determine his walking rate. They find that Henri’s walking rate is 1 meter per second.

Henri challenges Emile to a walking race. Because Emile’s walking rate is faster, Emile gives Henri a 45-meter head start. Emile knows his brother would enjoy winning the race, but he does not want to make the race so short that it is obvious his brother will win.
• How long should the race be so that Henri will win in a close race? Give evidence to support your answer.

With a 45-meter head start, Emile will catch up to Henri after 30 seconds at the 75-meter mark. The race should be less than 30 seconds or 75 meters, depending on how they determine the length of the race.
Possible student answers may include tables, graphs, words, and diagrams. Some examples include the following.
In Ms. Kreuger’s class some students used tables and graphs to find the length of the race and other information about the race.
• How can a table or graph be used to find the length of the race?

You can make a table for how far both brothers will walk in a given amount of time and see when they will be in the same place at the same time. By graphing the distance both brothers will walk in a given amount of time, you can see when they will be in the same place at the same time by seeing when the lines intersect.
• How does the walking rate of each brother show up in the table and graph?
The walking rate shows up in the graph as the steepness of the line. In the table, it is the constant change in distance for each second of time.
• What information does the y-intercept of each graph represent in terms of the race?

The y-intercept of each graph represents where the brothers start the race.

At 0 seconds, Emile is at the starting line; at 0 seconds, Henri is already 45 meters past the starting line.
• After 20 seconds, how far apart are the brothers? How is this distance represented in the table and on the graph?

After 20 seconds, the brothers are 15 meters apart. At 20 seconds, Emile has walked 2.5(20) = 50 meters and Henri has walked 1(20) = 20 meters, which is 65 meters from the starting line (because he had a 45-meter head start). So, 65 meters – 50 meters = 15 meters. The distance is represented in the table by subtracting the positions of the brothers at 20 seconds, and the distance is represented in the graph by the vertical distance between the brothers’ graphs.
• Is the point (26, 70) on the graph or table of one of the brothers? If so, what information does it represent?
After 26 seconds, Henri is at the 45m + 1(26m) = 71-meter mark and Emile is at the 2.5(26) = 65-meter mark.
• Mary wrote the inequality: 45 + t < 2.5t. What information was she looking for?

The left side of the inequality shows Henri’s distance after t seconds and the right side of the inequality shows Emile’s distance after t seconds. So Mary is looking for when Henri’s distance from the starting line is less than Emile’s distance from the starting line.
Amit wrote equations to represent the relationships between time and distance. He wrote
DEmile = 2.5t for Emile and DHenri = 45 + 1t for Henri
He makes five claims. Are they correct? Explain.
I can tell the walking rate and y-intercept from the equation.
I can determine which of the two lines will be steeper from the equation.
I can find the time when Emile catches Henri, by setting the expressions for distance equal.
Then find the value for t that makes the equation true.
to find the distance the brothers are apart for any given second t.

Claim 1 is true. The walking rate is the number that is multiplied by t in each equation and the y-intercept is the number that is added. So, Emile’s walking rate is 2.5 meters per second and Henri’s walking rate is 1 meter per second. Emile’s y-intercept is 0 m (because no extra amount gets added) and Henri’s y-intercept is 45 m.
Claim 2 is true. Since you can see their walking rates in the equation, the larger walking rate will result in a steeper line when graphed. So Emile’s graph will be steeper.
Claim 3 is false. Both equations do represent linear relationships, but Emile’s relationship is also proportional because at 0 seconds he has traveled 0 meters.
Claim 4 is true. By setting the expressions equal, we are finding the time when they are both the same distance from the starting line.

Claim 5 is true. The expression starts with them being 45 apart with the head start. Then subtracts the difference between their walking rates. The expression could be 45 – 1.5t which is the distance they start apart minus the difference in their walking rates for each measure of time.
Describe some strategies for solving problems that involve linear relationships.
Table: If you are given the value of one variable you can find the corresponding value of the other variable.

Graph: Find the known value on the axis. Then, follow that value up or over until you intercept the line. Look over the to other axis to find the corresponding value. You will get the coordinate pair (x,y). One value of the pair is the known value, the other is the solution.
Equation: You can find values for the y variable by substituting values for the x variable.

Note that students will solve equations such as, 100 = 2x +45, symbolically in the next Investigation. Some students may use guess and check, numerical reasoning, fact families, tables, or graphs to solve equations at this time.
Numeric Reasoning. You can guess and check or use fact families to find values.
Problem 2.1 Henri and Emile’s Race: Developing Strategies to Find a Solution

In the Initial Challenge students look at the context of a young boy challenging his older brother to a race. Students explore the question, “How long should the race be so that the younger brother wins in a close race?” In the What If Situations students will investigate finding the point of intersection of two linear relationships using a graph, a table, or numeric reasoning.
Describe some strategies for solving problems that involve linear relationships.
Begin by having students list several equations from Investigation 1 that represent linear relationships.

• Which relationship has the greatest rate of change?
  • Which relationship(s) has a graph that crosses the y-axis at a point with a positive y-coordinate? With a y-coordinate of zero? With a negative y-coordinate?
Tell the story of the race between Emile and his younger brother, Henri. This Problem is intended to show what knowledge students already have concerning linear relationships.

• What do we know about the race at the beginning?
  • If you were watching this race, what would you see happening with the brothers?
Encourage students to think about how the race can be represented mathematically. Do not look for answers to these questions at this time.

• What data would you collect to document what happens in the race?
  • What are the variables that you would keep track of?
  • How could you represent the data to show what happens as they race?

Implementation Note: You might have a short summary after the Initial Challenge. This will give students a chance to share their strategies and how they made sense of the race question before going on to answer more detailed questions. You may want to use the What If Situations to push the conversation during the Summary. Ask the questions and pause for students to think about and record their answers, then engage the class in a discussion of ideas.
Circulate and ask groups to explain their thinking. Put the emphasis on what evidence the group will use to justify their conclusion.

If students hesitate about how to begin, you might offer suggestions for how to represent the data of the race. Ask the questions, but do not look for answers at this time. The questions are to suggest representation strategies.

• How might a table help?
  • How might a graph help?
  • Would an equation help?
  • Would a diagram or picture help?
  • What do we know about the race at the beginning?
  • If you were watching this race, what would you see happening with the brothers?
Select student work that will show how to use a table, graph, or numeric reasoning to find how long the race will be. Use this student work to show the connections between the representations.
• How did your group interpret the Initial Challenge? What strategy did you use?

• How do the table and graph representations help us answer questions about the length of the race?
  • What does it mean when the graphs for the brothers intersect?
  • How would I find the same information in the table?
  • Looking at the table, how can we find the walking rate for each brother? What if we look at the graph?
  • How does the starting point of each brother in the race show up in the graph?
  • What expression represents Emile’s race? Henri’s?
  • How can I look at the table or graph and know which brother is ahead in the race?
  • In What If Situation B, we see that Amit wrote equations to represent the relationships between time and distance. How do these equations represent the situation for each brother?
  • What information from the claims can you answer by looking at the equations?
As you finish the mathematical discussions, have students reflect on the Now What Do You Know question(s).

problems.title: MSA 2.2 Comparing Cost Relationships
problems.subtitle: Using Tables and Graphs to Solve Problems

text: All the linear relationships we have studied so far can be written in the form y = ax, y = ax + b, or y = b + ax. In these equations, y depends on x.
The coordinates of the y-intercept for the graph shown above are (0, b). To save time, we sometimes refer to the number b, rather than the coordinates of the point (0, b), as the y-intercept.
A coefficient is the number that multiplies a variable in an equation. The a in y = ax + b is the coefficient of x, so ax means a times x.
A solution of an equation is an ordered pair that makes the equation true and lies on the graph of the line. For example, in the equation that represents the distance Henri walks
(0,45) is a solution to the equation.
When the coordinate values are substituted into the equation it is a true statement;
What does the point (0,45) represent in the context of the race?
If the coordinates of a point on the graph or values in the table are (t, 48), what is the value of t?
If the coordinates of a point on the graph or values in the table are (10, d), what is the value of d?

Ms. Chang’s class decides to give T-shirts to each person who participates in the walkathon. They obtain the cost of the T-shirts from two different companies. Mighty Tee charges $49 plus $1 per T-shirt. No-Shrink Tee charges $4.50 per T-shirt. Ms. Chang writes the following equations to represent the relationships relating cost to the number of T-shirts:
The number of T-shirts is n. CMighty is the cost in dollars for Mighty Tee. CNo-Shrink is the cost in dollars for No-Shrink Tee.
• Which company should they choose? Give evidence for your answer.

The amount spent on t-shirts will be the same if the class buys 14 t-shirts. If they want to buy fewer than 14 t-shirts, they should choose No-Shrink Tee; if they want to buy more than 14 t-shirts, they should choose Mighty Tee.
• Explain how a graph or a table could be helpful in making your decision
A graph or table would tell you how much you would spend on n t-shirts from each company.
A graph would give a visual of the inequality that No-Shrink is cheaper until 14 shirts. Then after more than 14 shirts, Mighty would be cheaper with a line below the other company’s.
In the graph, we can find where the two lines intersect. This shows the point when both companies have the same cost for the same number of shirts.
Before that point, we can see that No-Shrink is cheaper, because the y-values are below the y-values of Mighty. After that point, we can see that the y-values of Might are less that No-Shrink.

On a table, you can see how the money amounts change for equal increments of change in the number of shirts. No-Shrink is cheaper until you get to 14 shirts, when the companies both would charge $63. For more than 14 shirts, Mighty would have a cheaper cost.
In the table, we can find where we have the same cost for the same number of shirts.
Before that, we can see that No-Shrink is cheaper, because the y-values are less than the y-values of Mighty. After that point, we can see that the y-values of Might are less that No-Shrink.

This informal comparison of two linear equations will be formalized in Grade 8. Students will learn that when you find the point at which the costs are the same for the same number of shirts, it is solving a system of linear equations. These informal experiences lay the foundation for connecting ideas in more formal learning later on.
Situation A. Monica, Roland, and Naomi’s Strategies
Explain how each strategy can or cannot help each student decide which company to choose.
T-shirts when the cost of the two companies is equal.
I assumed that the class had $120 to spend.
I found the number of T- shirts that satisfy this inequality.
This tells when the company costs are the same for the same number of shirts.
This helps use decide when one company switches from being more expensive to less expensive.
If the class only had $120 to spend, they should try to maximize the number of shirts they can buy.
We know that 14 t-shirts costs $63. And, after that amount, Mighty would be cheaper. So, they might go with Mighty for the whole order. 26 shirts for $4.50 each is $117.
Or, they could order 14 t-shirts from No-Shrink and pay $63. Then order 12 from Mighty for $54. This would give them 26 shirts for $117.
Or, to get the most shirts for their money, they could order 17 t-shirts from No-Shrink and pay $66. Then order 12 from Mighty for $54. This would give them 29 shirts for $120.
We can put each expression in the inequality shown. Then find the value for when Mighty is less than No-Shrink.
Students might use the values on the table or points on the graph.
Then might guess and check quantities to find when the inequality is true.
Or, students might reason about the equation to think about how to solve the inequality.
At 14 shirts they are the same. So, more than 14 will make the inequality true.
Situation B. Using Tables, Graphs, and Equations
Explain how you could use a table, graph, or equation to answer each question about the companies in the Initial Challenge.
• For each company, find the costs of 20 T-shirts?
Table: Find 20 shirts on the table; the cost will be in the other column.
Graph: Trace the lines to find out which y-coordinate corresponds with an x-coordinate of 20.
Equation: Evaluate the equation for an independent value of 20 t-shirts.
• For each company what is the number of T-shirts you can buy for $135. Less than $135? Greater than $135?

Table: The cost closest to $135 without exceeding $135 will show how many t-shirts you can buy. Then all table entries with smaller numbers of t-shirts will cost less than $135, and all table entries with larger numbers of t-shirts will cost more than $135.

Graph: Trace the lines to find out which x-coordinate corresponds with a y-coordinate of $135. Then all x-coordinates to the left of that point will be numbers of t-shirts that you could buy for less than $135, and all x-coordinates to the right of that point will be numbers of t-shirts that you could buy for more than $135.

Equation: For a dependent value of $135, evaluate the number of t-shirts needed. Then all numbers of t-shirts less than that value would cost less than $135, and all numbers of t-shirts greater than that value would cost more than $135.
• Nic saw the point (50,99) on one of his graphs. Which graph was he using? What information was he looking for?
This would be on the graph for Mighty. CMighty = 49 + n = 49 + 50 = 99
The following table represents the costs from another company, The Big Tee.
• Compare the cost for this company to the costs for the other two companies.

The cost for n t-shirts for The Big T is $34 + $2.5n. The cost per t-shirt for this company is $2.50 and the down payment (or cost for no t-shirts) is $34. The cost per t-shirt is less than No-Shrink Tee and greater than Mighty Tee.

tiles.title: Table showing how values of C are generated

text: • How many T-Shirts can you buy for $84?
If 12 shirts cost $64 and every 2 shirts add another $5, we can add-on 8 shirts for another $20.
Guess and Check reasoning – knowing that each shirt costs $2.50
We can check the answer using the equation:
• Are any of the relationships represented by the three companies linear? Proportional? Explain.
The relationships represented by the three companies are all linear because they involve constant rates of change.

Only the No-Shrink Tee’s cost relationship is proportional because there is no down payment. So, to find the cost for a number of shirts, we can multiply by the unit rate (which is the constant of proportionality) because there is no amount that you have to add-in,
How do you know if the ordered pair of numbers for a point on a graph or table is a solution to an equation? How can you use a table or graph to find a solution for an equation?

An ordered pair is a solution to an equation when evaluating the equation for the first coordinate results in the second coordinate. For example, you try the x-value of the coordinate pair in the equation and see if you get the y-value.
You can use a graph to find a solution for an equation by selecting a point that lies on the line. You can check the solution by using the coordinate pair in the equation.
You can use a table to find a solution for an equation by choosing a row of the table.
Note: If the equations are of the form y = ax or y = a + x then students can use what they learned in 6th grade to solve these using fact families, graphs, tables, or other numerical reasoning.
Problem 2.2 Comparing Cost Relationships: Using Tables and Graphs to Solve Problems

In the Initial Challenge students investigate two T-shirt companies to find the best deal. They are given equations and have to find solutions. In the What If Situations students will look at specific strategies of using tables, graphs, and numeric reasoning to solve the problems.
How do you know if the ordered pair of numbers for a point on a graph or table is a solution to an equation? How can you use a table or graph to find a solution for an equation?
Students were introduced to the vocabulary word “coefficient” in the Grade 6 Variables and Patterns Unit. Briefly review coefficient and “y-intercept” using the previous Problem.

Discuss with students that they have been finding solutions of an equation when they were given one variable and found another or that a coordinate pair of a point on a graph will substitute into the equation. Using tables, graphs, and numerical relationships, they have found many solutions to an equation to answer questions in this and in previous Units.

Tell the story of the cost plans offered by two T-shirt companies. Challenge students to pick a company and justify their answer. After answering the Initial Challenge, students may continue working on the What If Situations. These Situations may encourage students to refine their justifications. Have students begin this Problem independently and then work with a partner.
As you circulate and listen to students, ask questions to prompt their thinking. Do not elicit answers at this time. Use the Summary to bring out the answers.

• How might a table help? Graph?
  • Can you use the equations to help answer the question?
  • What is the cost of one shirt from each plan? 10 shirts? 20 shirts?
  • What is the coefficient in each equation? What does this tell you about the T-shirt costs?
  • How do the solutions to the questions show up in the graph? In the table? In the equation?

Look for interesting strategies. Call on these students in the Summary to share their strategies. Be sure to have a representative sample of the strategies presented. Students may choose to use numerical reasoning, tables, graphs, or equations.

Call on students to share their strategies. Be sure to have a representative sample of the strategies presented. Students may choose to use numerical reasoning, tables, graphs, or equations. Question students to explain their methods used to find when the two cost plans are equal. You may want to orchestrate the Summary so that at least one student presents Situation B with a table, another student with a graph, and a third student with an equation to reinforce how to use each representation.

• How did The Big Tee company in What If Situation C compare to Mighty and No-Shrink?
  • Which representation seems most convenient for solving this Problem?
  • How can you compare which company is a better deal when they all have different ways of charging for the shirts?
  • If I know how much money I have to spend, how can I find how many T-shirts I can buy from the different companies?
  • In a linear situation, describe how you can find a value of a variable if the value of the other variable is known. hits the line.
  • What does it mean for relationships to be proportional?
  • How can you tell if relationships are linear?
As you finish the mathematical discussions, have students reflect on the Now What Do You Know question(s).

problems.title: MSA 2.3 Connecting Tables, Graphs, and Equations to Solutions

text: Look again at Alana’s pledge plan from Problem 1.3. Suppose A represents the amount raised in dollars and d represents the distance walked in kilometers. We can express this plan with the equation A = 5 + 0.5d.
The point (14, 12) is on the graph of Alana’s pledge plan.
Write a question we could answer by locating this point.
How can we use the equation for Alana’s pledge plan to check the answer to the question we made up?
How can we use a graph to find the number of kilometers that Alana walks if a sponsor donates $17? How could we use an equation to answer this question?
In this Problem, we will investigate similar questions relating to pledge plans for a walkathon.
Consider the following pledge plans. In each equation, y is the amount pledged in dollars by each sponsor and x is the distance walked in kilometers.
• What information does the equation give about the pledge plan? Does the plan make sense? Explain why.

Plan 1: A sponsor pays $5 for every kilometer walked, but you pay the sponsor $3 (or give the sponsor a t-shirt that costs $3). This makes sense because the sponsor is paying money for each kilometer walked, but you are only giving them one donation/t-shirt.

Plan 2: A sponsor pays $6 and then you give the sponsor $1 for every kilometer you walk. Students will say that the negative rate does not make sense because you give back money. But some may suggest that the walker in Plan 2 collects $6 and promises to walk 15 kilometers. If she does not walk the 15 kilometers, then she pays back $1 for each kilometer not walked. In this case, it is necessary to change what x represents to the number of kilometers not walked.
Plan 3: A sponsor donates a fixed amount of $2 no matter how far you walk. This makes sense because it’s like a one-time donation.
• How might a table or graph of the equation help answer questions about the pledge plans.
A table or graph of the equation could help answer questions about the pledge plans by giving you a visual of how much money students raise after walking various numbers of kilometers.
• Which plan in the Initial Challenge has a graph that contains the point (2,4)?
• What question could you answer by locating this point.
Sample question: For Plan 2, how much money would you get if you walked 2 kilometers?
• Which plan has a graph that you can use to find the solution for 8 = 5x – 3?
Plan 1. The coordinates of the point that represents the solution (2.2, 8) shows that the student raises $8 by walking 2.2 kilometers.
All of the following coordinates are in the table of one of the plans from the Initial Challenge. Two coordinates have a missing value:
• Find the missing values. Explain how you found which plan has the coordinates.
The coordinate pair (4,2) does not satisfy Plan 1.
So, it either satisfies Plan 2 or Plan 3.
The ordered pair (?,-4) could not possibly satisfy the equation for Plan 3 (which would give y-values of 2 every x-value).
So, Plan 2 is the only plan that can have all three coordinate pairs.
Students might search the tables, estimate from the graphs, guess & check, or evaluate the equations to find the missing values.
• Write a question you could answer by finding the missing value.
Possible answer: For Plan 2, how much money does each sponsor pledge if you walk 1.2 kilometers? For Plan 2, how many kilometers does the walker need to walk to owe each sponsor $4?
• Find the value of y when x = 7?
• Find the value of x when y = 32?
Note: Some students will just say that x = 7, because of question #1.
• Sally is trying to figure out if the relationships represented by the three plans are linear. How can you help her decide by looking at the equations?

All the relationships are linear because the y-values change by a constant amount when the x-values increase by 1. Even though the y-values increase, decrease, or stay the same depending on which plan you look at, the rate of change is always constant.
• Yvonne claims that only Plan 3 is proportional. Do you agree? Explain why.
She is incorrect. None of the plans are proportional, because they all have non-zero y-intercepts. Also, you could not write a proportion from the table values.
Describe the advantages and disadvantages of using tables, graphs, and symbolic methods to solve equations.
A point on a graph represents a solution to an equation and a possible table entry.
Graphs show all possible values that solve the equation to give you a visual way of looking at the pattern, but they often require you to estimate in order to find the solution.

Tables give you many of values that solve the equation. And it is clear how the independent and dependent variables are paired in each solution. However, tables cannot show all of the solutions. Sometimes you have to extend the tables a long way or search to find a solution in-between values on your table.
Symbolic methods can help you solve the equation for any value, but the calculations can be more time consuming.
Problem 2.3 Connecting Tables, Graphs, and Equations to Solutions

In the Initial Challenge students investigate various pledge plans from sponsors of the walkathon. The plans are represented by equations. In the What If Situations students will connect equations to graphs and tables and use all representations to find solutions.
Describe the advantages and disadvantages of using tables, graphs, and symbolic methods to solve equations.
Remind students about the three students and their pledge plans from Investigation 1. Display Teaching Aid 2.3A: Alana’s Pledge Plan.

• Write a question that could be answered using the point (14, 12).
  • How can you use the equation for Alana’s plan to check the answer to the question you wrote?
  • How can you use a graph to find the number of kilometers that Alana walked if each sponsor donated $17?

Now pose the challenge in the Problem of looking at three other pledge plans. Tell students they need to decide whether an equation represents a reasonable pledge plan for the walkathon if the idea is to raise money for charity. They will decide which points are solutions of the equation and whether the y-values increase, decrease, or stay the same as the x-values increase.

• What do you notice and what do you wonder about the three plans?
  • Consider how much you would raise if you walked one kilometer. Two kilometers. Three kilometers.
Students may need help with the negative coefficient in the equation for Plan 2. You can ask students to explain why the line slants down or why the relationship is decreasing.

• Does the table help you decide whether the graph of the relationship is increasing or decreasing?
  • Pick a point on this line. Can you find this point in the table? Explain.
  • How do you know the ordered pair you picked is a solution to the equation?

As you are circulating during the Explore, listen to how students are making decisions on which representations to use to solve problems. Select students to share how they used tables, graphs, or symbolic methods in the Summary. Use this work to lead conversations on the connections between the representations and the advantages and disadvantages of each.
Revisit constant rate of change in the context of equations and connect the rate to tables and graphs of linear relationships. Suggested questions

• What is the amount raised per kilometer under each plan?  
  • How does each rate appear in a table? In a graph? In an equation?
  • What information does the y-intercept represent in each plan?
  • Do the plans make sense? Explain.

Let students share their ideas with the main focus on the rate, intercepts of the graphs, and solutions of the equations. Most students will say that the negative rate does not make sense. It means you give money back. However, students are very creative and may suggest something plausible.

Be sure to go over the answers to the What If Situations. Check to make sure students understand the relationship between the points on a line, values in a table, and the solutions of the equation for that line. Have students share their solutions and their strategies for each part of the Problem. Ask for explanations.
Students should be making the connection between a specific solution of an equation and the more general relationship between two variables for the related equation.

• How are the equations 12 = 5x - 3, -8 = 5x - 3, and 27 = 5x - 3 related to y = 5x - 3?
  • How can you find the missing value of x?
As you finish the mathematical discussions, have students reflect on the Now What Do You Know question(s).

investigations.title: MSA Investigation 3 Solving Linear Equations Symbolically

text: Throughout this Unit, we have been solving equations with two variables. Sometimes the value of one variable is known, and we want to find the value of the other variable. In this Investigation, we will continue to find the value of a variable without using a table or a graph or numeric reasoning. We will also learn to use symbolic methods to solve a linear equation.
In the last Investigation, we examined the patterns in the table, graph, and equation for the relationship relating Alana’s distance d and money earned A in the walkathon.
Suppose Alana raises $20 from a sponsor, how many kilometers did she walk?
We can use numeric reasoning, a table, a graph, or equation to find the value of the other variable to find the answer.
Locate the point on the graph with the value $20 which is (30,20).
Find the coordinate in the table where $20 is the amount earned. This is at 30 km.
15 is the amount earned for walking d km.
This question can also be represented by substituting 20 for A in the equation. We can use the equation 20 = 5 + 0.5d to find d.
How could we solve the equation 20 = 5+ 0.5d to find the distance that Alana walks if she earns $20?
In this Investigation we will develop strategies for solving the equation of the form y = ax + b symbolically.

To raise more money, Ms. Chang’s class decides to hold a raffle. They put some gold coins into a pouch, and people will guess the amount of coins in the pouch. At the end of the Walkathon the class will give the pouch to the person who guessed the exact number of gold coins.

To make the contest interesting, they decide to add a code for the amount of money in the pouch. The code consists of an equation using gold coins and pouches. Each pouch has the same number of gold coins.
The code below indicates that the number of dollars in the two pouches and 5 loose coins on the left side of the equation is equal to $11 as shown on the right side of the equation.
The class made up several other codes. For each code, the total number of coins on each side of the equation is the same and each pouch contains the same number of coins.

• What is the number of gold coins in each pouch?
  • How can you check your answer?
Write down your steps so that someone else could follow your steps to find the number of coins in a pouch.
Split the bags and coins equally and got 2 coins in a bag: $2 = P
Crossed off 2 coins from each side: P = $4

Possible Student Answer:

Original Code: 3P = 2P + $12

Crossed of 12 coins from each side and got 12 coins in a bag: P= $12
Split the bags and coins equally and got 9 coins in a bag P = $9
Crossed off 2 bags from each side: P + $3 = $12
Crossed off 3 coins from each side: P = $9
Split the amounts on each side equally and got 6 coins in a bag: $6 = P
In Code 2, I thought of the left-hand side of the equation as having two groups. Each group contained one pouch and two coins. I used the following steps to help find the number of coins in a pouch.
• Noah looked at Nicole’s strategy and claimed that she was applying the Distributive Property. Is Noah’s claim correct? Explain.

Yes, Noah is correct. Nicole is applying the Distributive Property. The left side of the equation can be thought of as 2(x+2), or two times a group of 1 pouch plus 2 coins. This situation can also be thought of as 2 pouches and 2 sets of 2 coins, or 2x+2(2). The Distributive Property states that these two expressions are equivalent.
• Zoey thought that Nicole was just dividing both sides of the original equation by 2. Is she correct? Explain.
Zoey is also correct because in order to solve the problem, Nicole did have to divide both sides by 2.
• Can Nicole's strategy be used for other coin and pouch situations? Explain why or why not.
Nicole's strategy involves removing equivalent amounts from both sides of the equation until she is left with “pouch = 4 gold coins.”

tiles.title: Remove equivalent amounts from each side

text: Nicole’s method could work in other situations in which each side can be equally divided into the same number of groups.
Aman made up another Clue, but then he forgot the number of coins he put in the pouches. But he did remember that there were 5 pouches and 10 coins with a total of 35 dollars.
• What might the pouches and coin picture look like?
Answers will vary but should represent 5 pouches + 10 coins on one side of the equation and 35 coins on the other side. Such as the following.
• How many dollars are in a pouch?
A local merchant donates $200 for the Walkathon. She wants the amount recorded in a code using B to represent the number of coins in one bag.
6B + $20 = $200. How much money is in each bag?
• Mateo wrote two expressions that could be codes to represent the $200. For each expression how much money is in each bag.
• Design another clue that the merchant could use. Give it to a classmate to solve.
Student answers will vary. Example: For a clue with the expression, 9B + 20. The equation would be 9B + 20 = 200. The solution would be B = $20.
Pouches with an unknown number of coins and coins are represented with an equation. What strategies can you use to find the number of coins in each pouch? How do you know if your answer is correct?

You can do the same thing to both sides of the equation to find the number of coins in each pouch. You can check your answer by substituting the value you found back into the pouches and see if the clue comes out correctly.

The Initial Challenge introduces students to symbolic ways of solving linear equations with one unknown. Equations are represented pictorially as coins (constant term) and pouches that hold an unknown number of coins (variables). Students explore the properties of equality pictorially as they find the number of coins in a pouch. The What If Situations will provide a transition into solving equations symbolically.

Pouches that hold an unknown number of coins and coins are represented with an equation. What strategies can you use to find the number of coins in each pouch? How do you know if your answer is correct?
Review the strategies students have used for solving equations in this Unit: using a table, using a graph, and using numeric reasoning.

• Write two questions about Alana’s pledge plan that could be answered by the coordinates of the point (14, 12).
  • How can you use the equation for Alana’s plan to check the answer to the question you made up?
  • How can you use a graph to find the number of kilometers that Alana walked if a sponsor donated $17?
  • How can you use a graph to solve 20 = 5 + 0.5d? What would the answer mean?
Display Learning Aid 3.1: Pouches and Coins. Tell the class about the pouches and gold coins used in the Kingdom of Montarek.

• The number of gold coins on each side of the equal sign is the same, but some coins are hidden in the pouches.  
  • In each situation, each pouch contains the same number of one-dollar gold coins.  
  • The challenge is to find the number of coins in each pouch.
Encourage students to record their strategies. Using poster paper to have students record their work can help lead the Summary discussions.

• What does “equality” mean? What does the equal sign tell us?  
  • How can we maintain equality?  
  • How do you know if your answer is correct?

As you are circulating during the Explore, look for strategies that students are using to find the number of coins in a pouch for each code. Look for students that are “getting rid of” common coins or “getting rid of” common pouches first. Look for how students are sharing or dividing the coins into the pouches. Listen for the informal language students are using that can be used in the next Problem to develop a procedure for solving equations symbolically.
If your students recorded their work on poster paper, display the posters and give the class time to examine the various strategies using a Gallery Walk.
Have students share all of the correct strategies they used (and some incorrect strategies if discussing them would be helpful in deepening students’ understanding of equality).
Display Teaching Aid 3.1B: Nicole’s Strategy and make sure students understand how the Distributive Property is being used.
