• Can you use the Distributive Property on any of the other equations?
  • Can you use the Distributive Property for Aman’s Code in Situation B?
After all of the Situations have been discussed, ask:

• Did everyone use the same first step in each equation?
  • What are some common strategies that we can use to maintain equality?
  • How is designing a code, like you did in Situation C, different from figuring out a code, like you did in the other questions?
If there is time begin to make the transition from pouches to variables using Code 4. If not, this can be used to Launch Problem 3.2.
As you finish the mathematical discussions, have students reflect on the Now What Do You Know question(s).

In the last Problem, we used pictures of pouches and gold coins to solve equations. Our solutions maintained the equality of coins on both sides of the equal sign. For example, we might have removed (or subtracted) the same number of coins on both sides of the equation. To better understand how to maintain equality, let’s look first at numerical statements.
The equation 85 = 70 + 15 states that the quantities 85 and 70 + 15 are equal.
What do we have to do to maintain equality if we:

• subtract 15 from the left-hand side of the original equation?
  • add 10 to the right-hand side of the original equation?
  • divide the left-hand side of the original equation by 5?
  • multiply the right-hand side of the original equation by 4?
The picture below shows a situation from Problem 3.1.

Because the number of gold coins in each pouch is unknown, we can let x represent the number of coins in one pouch. We can let 1 represent the value of one gold coin. Then this situation can be represented with one of the following equivalent equations:
Recall from several of the Grade 6 grade units that we have been solving linear equations of the form y = ax and y = x + b. We used tables, graphs, and numeric reasoning.
In this Problem, we will revisit problems that involve linear situations with pouches and coins, but we will also use symbolic equations to represent our solution process to equations of the form,
y = ax + b or ax + b = cx + d.
Suppose x represents the number of coins in one pouch and 1 represents the value of one coin in the following situations.

• Write an equation to represent each code.
  • Are there other possibilities for the equations that you could write? Explain.
  • Use your equation to find the number of gold coins in each pouch. Check your answers.
Note: This may create a conversation about the possibility of a new coin worth 1/3 of a dollar.
A messenger has 6 pouches and 27 coins. There is a total of 105 coins.
• Write an equation to represent the situation. Then solve the equation to find the number of dollars in each pouch.
• AJ claims that there is more than one way to write the equation. Is he correct? Explain.
He is correct. For example, he could write 27 + 6P = 105.
• If there is more than one equation, will the solution for each equation be the same? Explain
Yes. For the example above, the Commutative Property of Addition tells you that the answer will be the same.
Use your strategies to solve each equation. Check your answer.
A messenger has 6 pouches and 30 coins. The total must be less than 102 coins
How would you write this inequality? What are some solutions?
We can solve the inequality by thinking of it as an equation:
Then, we can consider the solutions to P < 12. So, there could be 1 coin in each pouch, 2 coins in each pouch, 3 coins in each pouch, or up to 11 coins in each pouch to make this inequality true.
We can check to make sure that this is correct by entering a value into the inequality
66 + 30 < 102 is true so the solutions are correct.
Describe how the strategies you used to find the number of coins in a pouch is similar to finding the value of a variable in an equation?
You can apply the principles of equality repeatedly to the equation until you have isolated the variable on one side and a number on the other side.
Then you can check the solution by substituting the value of the variable into the original equation to see if the equation is true.
Problem 3.2 From Pouches to Variables: Writing and Solving Equations

In the Initial Challenge students translate the pictorial form of linear equations into symbolic linear equations in one variable. They use codes similar to Problem 3.1 to make this transition. In the What If Situations students will begin to use the properties of equality to solve the equations symbolically. They explore equivalent expressions that can represent a given situation involving pouches and coins.
Describe how the strategies you used to find the number of coins in a pouch is similar to finding the value of a variable in an equation.

Start by presenting the example at the beginning of the Introduction. Write the equation 85 = 70 + 15 on the board. Then, pose each of the questions in the Student Edition one at a time, always using the original equation.

If you did not make the transition from pouches and coins to variables and numbers at the end of the Summary for Problem 3.1, do so now. Be sure students have a general idea of the procedures. You might want to revisit one of the codes from Problem 3.1. As a part of the discussion, discuss how the pouches and coins can be represented by various equivalent expressions.
As you move from group to group, watch and listen to how students are discussing equivalent expressions. It will be important for them to be flexible with equivalent expressions.
Be sure students are recording their methods and checking their answers.

• What is your equation for the code?
  • What was the first thing you did with the pictorial equation to begin solving it?
  • How can you show this with your equation?
  • What did you do next? How can you show this with your equation?
  • How can you check your answer?
As you are circulating during the Explore listen for conversations students are having about the given contexts and about the contexts they create for What If Situation D.

Post the solutions around the room. Call on different students to describe how they solved the equations. Make sure you highlight equations in which students may have done something different for the first step. Some may begin by combining pouches (like terms), while others may start by removing coins.

• What did you do at each step to maintain equality?  
  • Is there another way to make the first step in the solution? Explain.
  • Are there other equations in which a different first step could be taken?
  • Look back over your work for each equation. What general rules were you using to solve the equations?
To move from pouches and coins to solving equations symbolically, discuss the What If Situations.

• In What if Situation A, what equation can we write to represent the pouches and coins code?  
  • Using the thinking that you were using with the visual equations, how do we find the value of x.
  • Next to your work, write down a similar method using the equation that represents this situation.
  • Describe a general method for solving equations.
Discuss that when solving an inequality, students can use what they know about solving equations to make sense of the solutions.

• In What If Situation C, we know that 6 pouches and 30 coins must be less than 102 coins. What if it were equal to 102 coins? How would we write that in symbols?
  • What would be the solution to the equation?
  • So, if 6 pouches and 30 coins must be less than 102 coins, or 6x + 30 < 102, what are possible answers for how many coins could be in each pouch?
  • If it were possible to have partial coins, would 11 ½ coins be a solution?
  • So, could there be more solutions than the ones you listed?
As you finish the mathematical discussions, have students reflect on the Now What Do You Know question(s).

To maintain the equality of two expressions, we can add, subtract, multiply, or divide each side of the equality by the same number. These are called the properties of equality. In the last Problem, we applied properties of equality and numbers to find a solution to an equation.
Does it make sense to think about negative numbers in a coin situation?
Does it make sense to think about fractions in a coin situation?
What are some situations where it makes sense to use fractions or negative

• Find a solution.
  • Record each step you take to find a solution.
  • Then, check your answer.

1. If 3x – 7 = y, find y when x = – 2/3
  2. If 3x – 7 = y, find x when y = – 5
  3. Mary thinks you could solve these equations with a graph or table. Is she correct? Explain why?
  4. Could you solve the equations in the Initial Challenge with a graph or table? Explain why.

3. Yes, if you had a graph of these equations, you would find the point on the line with the x-value that you are looking for (by looking at the x-axis), and then get the corresponding y-value by looking at the y-axis. If you had a table of these equations, you would find the entry with the x-value that you are looking for, and then get the corresponding y-value by looking at the other column of the table. You could also start either of these methods with a y-value and get the corresponding x-value.

4. You could solve these equations by using tables or graphs if you consider the expression on each side of the equation to be its own equation. So, you’d set y1 equal to the left side of the equation and y2 equal to the right side of the equation. Then to find the solution, you’d need to find the point where y1=y2. You could do this by making tables for each equation and looking for the points where y1=y2, or by graphing lines for each equation and looking for the points of intersection. For most cases in the Initial Challenge, y2 is equal to a constant value, but this method would also work when both y1 and y2 are equal to expressions involving x.

Forensic scientists can estimate a person’s height by measuring the length of certain bones, including the femur, the tibia, the humerus, and the radius. The table below gives the equations for the relationships between the length of each bone and the estimated height of males and females. These relationships were found by scientists after much study and data collection. In the table, F represents the length of the femur, T the length of the tibia, H the length of the humerus, R the length of the radius, and h the person’s height. All measurements are in centimeters.
• Do any of these equations represent linear relationships?
• Think of a question you could answer using this data. Explain how you would find the answer.
For example: If a person is 1.8 meters tall, about how long will their tibia be? You could set the height to be 180 cm and then solve for T.
• What information does the solution to the equality 61.412 + 2.317F = 150 tell you?
The solution to this equation will be the femur length for a female who is 150 cm tall.
• What does the solution to the inequality 61.412 + 2.317F < 150 tell you?
The solutions to this inequality will be all possible femur lengths for a female who is less than 150 cm tall.
Describe the strategies you can use to solve linear equations using the properties of operations and equality.

For symbolic methods, students’ explanations should include keeping expressions equivalent on both sides of the equal sign (e.g., adding 2 to each side, dividing each side by 3, etc.). Students should also include something about using order of operations correctly, although there are some exceptions (e.g., factoring as a first step). Students should also notice that if applying the Distributive Property is possible, then it may simplify the process.

Tables and graphs can also be used to solve linear equations. For example, the equation 2x – 5 = x + 7 can be solved by finding the point of intersection of y1 = 2x – 5 and y2 = x + 7 on a graphing calculator. Sometimes it is quicker to use symbolic methods. However, if students are experienced with using technology to create tables and graphs, and if several questions of this type are being asked, then tables or graphs might be more efficient.

Ratios within the human body are also helpful for artists. One common ratio used in drawing humans is a 1 to 8 for head to body, often called the 8 heads method. This means when drawing you can use the length of 8 heads to draw the height of human. Artists also use these head length markers to draw where other body parts are too. For example, you can draw the knees two head lengths up from the ground and the waist five head lengths up from the ground. These measurements are only averages and are not accurate for actual human measurements since we are all different. Some artists even prefer slightly different proportions such as 7.5 head lengths for the human height. However, this practice of using head length ratios is a common strategy for learning to draw humans.

In the Initial Challenge, students develop symbolic strategies for solving equations of the form px + q = r and p(x + q) = r, where p, q, and r are specific rational numbers. Students find the solutions to these linear equations using the properties of equality. In the What If Situations students will compare this method with other methods they have used for solving equations and look at inequalities.
Describe the strategies you can use to solve linear equations using the properties of operations and equality.

• Display these two equations: 2x + 10 = 16 and 2x - 10 = 16. How do the equations compare?
  • How would you begin solving these two equations?

• In the first equation, instead of subtracting 10 from each side, could we add -10 to each side?
  • In the Initial Challenge Set 1, how are the equations alike and how are they different?
Ask students to consider non-whole number and non-positive situations.

• We have not seen many negative numbers or fractions in the pouches and coins. Could we have negative numbers in a coin situation?
  • Could we have fractions in a coin situation?
Ask the class to solve the equations, show their work, and check their answers.
If students are puzzled as to how to proceed, ask:

• What would a visual equation with pouches and coins look like for the equation? (Answers will vary. For example, with 5x – 10 = 20, students might say that this would be 5 pouches with 10 coins, like the chips in Completely Rational, and is equal to 20 coins.)

Note: Some students will need to draw pouches and coins to help solidify this connection to symbols. Continue to allow them to do this and use them in parts of the Summary to help all students make connections.

Look for students’ explanations that include keeping expressions equivalent on both sides of the equal sign (e.g., adding 2 to each side, dividing each side by 3, etc.). Look for student work applying the Distributive Property.
﻿Teacher Moves: Agency, Identity, Ownership and Claim, Support, Question

Go over each part of the Problem. Call on different students to discuss their methods. After a group has presented their solutions, ask the class if they have any questions they want to ask the group. For example, encourage them to ask questions like the following:

• Why did you do this at step 2? 
  • Why did you not consider starting with a different step?
  • Was there a shorter way of getting to the answer?
While discussing the Initial Challenge Set 3, Teaching Aid 3.3A: Set 3 Student Thinking could be used if these ideas didn’t come out from your students.
While discussing What If Situation A, Teaching Aid 3.3B: Situation A can be used to show how a table and graph might be used to find the solutions to equations.

What If Situation B allows you to assess how comfortable your students are using the properties of equality to solve equations. With many previous equations, students may have used numerical reasoning, guess and check, tables, or graphs to find the solutions. With the quantities in the forensic formulas, solving the equation symbolically becomes an efficient way to find the solution.
Write the following equation on the board: 61.412 + 2.317F = 150

• How is this equation different from most of the equations in this Problem?
  • How can we solve this equation?
As you finish the mathematical discussions, have students reflect on the Now What Do You Know question(s).

In Problem 2.2, we used graphs and tables to find when the costs of two different plans for buying T-shirts were equal. The graphs of the two cost plans are shown below. CNo-Shrink represents the costs of the No-Shrink Tee. CMighty represents the costs of the Mighty Tee. The point of intersection of the two lines tells us when the costs for the two t-shirt plans are equal.
How could we use the two equations to find the coordinates of the point of intersection of the two lines?
That is, for what number of T-shirts n is CMighty = CNo-Shrink or 49+n = 4.5n?
How could we use the equation or its graph or table to find the number of T-shirts where the cost is less than $60?
That is, for values of n is
When either the value of x or y is known what strategies do we have for solving

• equations of the form y = ax+ b?
  • inequalities of the form ax +b < y or ax +b > y?

A local bakery, Fabulous Fabian’s Bakery, wants to set up a snack booth at the Walkathon. They will donate their profits to the school. To make a profit the business has to consider the expenses that might occur. For a bakery the cost might include cost of ingredients, labor charges, advertising, etc.
At Fabulous Fabian’s Bakery, the expenses E to make n cakes per month is given by the equation:
The income I for selling n cakes is given by the equation:
• What information do the numbers in each equation represent?

The first equation tells us about Fabian’s expenses, which are $825 each month (regardless of how many cakes he makes) plus an additional $3.25 for each cake he makes. The second equation tells us about Fabian’s income, which is $8.20 for each cake he sells.
• How many cakes does Fabian need to sell in order to start making a profit?
The profit is represented by I – E:
Fabian needs to sell 167 cakes in order to start making a profit.
Kevin drew the following graph to help him find the number of cakes sold to make a profit.
• Explain how Kevin could use his graph to determine Fabian’s profit.
Kevin can find when Fabian’s expenses and income are approximately equal. Where the lines intersect, we know that Fabian will make $0. After that, he will begin to make a profit.
• Kevin highlighted the vertical distance –330 between the two graphs. What does the –330 represent on the graph? What does it represent in the real world?
The 330 shows that the value of E is higher than I. In the real world, this shows that Fabian will spend $330 more in expenses than he will earn when he sells 100 cakes.
• Adia claims she can find the coordinates of the point of intersection by solving the equation, 8.20n = 825 + 3.25n. Is this possible? Explain. How does it help?

This is possible because (8.20n) represents the income and (825 + 3.25n) represents the expenses. So, by solving this equation, you are finding the point when income and expenses are equal, or where the two lines intersect.
• If Kevin sells 125 cakes, is he losing or making money? Explain why.
Losing. Looking at the graphs, Income (pink line) is lower than the Expenses (blue line) until after 150 cakes. So, he will lose money until he sells more than 150 cakes.
• Fabian uses the equation P = Income – Expenses to predict the profit. He wrote P = 8.20n – (825 + 3.25n). Does this make sense? Explain.
Yes, since he wants to subtract expenses from income for a given number of cakes, he can subtract the expenses expression from the income expression to give an expression for overall profit.
• Adia rewrites Fabian’s profit equation as P = 4.95n – 825. Is she correct? Explain.
Yes, this equation will give the same result as Fabian’s. Her equation gives the profit for each cake and subtracts the fixed, monthly expenses.

Situation C. Fabian’s Profit Inequality

Fabian and Billie are looking for ways to express how express how to find the number of cakes needed to make a profit. Explain why each representation does or does not make sense.

The inequality statement does make sense, because it says that they want their profit to be greater than their income – expenses. The number line does make sense because it shows all possible values of n for which they have a profit.

Describe how you can solve an equation of the form ax + b = y?

Describe how you can solve an inequality of the form ax + b < c or ax + b > c?

If you have an equation of the form y = ax+b and you know what the value of y is, you can find the solution using a table, graph, or equation.

On a table, you can find the needed value of y and look at the value of x. This is the same as finding the coordinate pair on the graph.

Using a graph, you can find the point of intersection of y1 = ax + b and y2 = y to solve the equation.

You can use the equation: subtract b from y and divide by a to solve for x. If you have an equation of the form y = ax+b and you know what the value of x is, you can substitute the value of x into the equation and compute the value of y.

If you have an inequality of that form, then you can use algebraic methods to solve the associated equation as before. Then check a few values greater or less than the equation’s solution in the original inequality to determine if the solutions to the inequality should be greater than or less than the solution to the associated equation.

investigations.title: MSA Investigation 4 Another Look at Linear Relationships: Connecting Rates and Ratios

problems.title: MSA 4.1 Preparing for the Walkathon
problems.subtitle: Using the Ratio of Rise to Run

text: All of the patterns of change you have explored in this Unit involved rates of change. For example, we worked with walking rates expressed in meters per second and pledge rates expressed in dollars per kilometer. In these situations, we found that the rate a affects the following in a linear relationship represented by y = ax + b:

• the steepness of the graph
  • how the y-values in the table change for each unit change in the x-values
  • and if b = 0, then the relationship is also proportional
In this Investigation, we will explore another way to express the rates of change.

Climbing stairs is good exercise, so some athletes run up and down stairs as part of their training. Some students in Ms. Chang's class decided to run up and down stairs to prepare for their Walkathon. The steepness of stairs determines how difficult they are to climb. By investigating the steepness of stairs, we can find another important way to describe the steepness of a line.
Carpenters have developed the guidelines below to ensure that the stairs they build are relatively easy for a person to climb. Steps are measured in inches.

• The run plus twice the rise should be between 24 and 26 inches.
  • The rise plus the run for each step should be between 17 and 19 inches.
The steepness of stairs is determined by the ratio of the rise to the run for each step. The rise and run are labeled in the photo below.

tiles.title: Rise and Run of a set of stairs

text:
• Access to various sets of stars to measure
  • Measuring device, such as, tape measure or ruler
  • Paper and pencil or other materials to record your results, such as Learning Aid 4.1

• Measure the rise and run for a few stairs
  • Record the ratios of the rise to the run
  • Repeat for a new set of stairs

• Determine the steepness of a set of stairs in your school or home.
  • How can you describe the steepness of the stairs?
  • Is the steepness the same between any two consecutive steps?
  • How do the stairs you measured compare the carpenters' guidelines
Student answers will vary. Interesting situations to think about include: spiral staircases, school stairs, large steps (like at a museum), etc.

Example: 7.25 in. to 11.25 inches for the rise to the run, or approximately 0.70 for the ratio of rise to run. This is the same for every step in the staircase. The ratio of rise to run is not within the carpenter’s guidelines.

A set of stairs is being built for the front of the new Arch Middle School. The ratio of rise to run is 7 to 11.
  • Is this ratio within the carpenters’ guidelines?

content.text:
2(rise) + run = 2(7) + 11 = 14 + 11 = 25, which is between 24 and 26 inches. 
Rise + run = 7 + 11 = 18, which is between 17 and 19 inches.
Yes, these stairs meet the carpenters’ guidelines. Note that a scaled-up equivalent ratio of 14 to 22 would not meet the guidelines.

text: • Make a sketch of a set of stairs that meet this ratio. Label the lengths of the rise and run of a step. Does everyone in your class have the same sketch? Explain.

content.text:
Student answers will vary.
Example: a set of stairs with a height of 3.5 inches and a depth of 5.5 inches.

tiles.title: Stairs with rise of 3.5 inches and run of 5.5 inches

text: Not everyone in the class will have the same sketch because even the same ratio can be represented by different numbers. And, some students will have measured different stairs.
• Write an equation that represents the relationship between rise and run.

content.text:
Student answers will vary based on their stairs.
Example answer using the stairs at Arch Middle School, rise = (7/11)run.

text: • How is the ratio of rise to run represented in the graph? Equation?

content.text: The ratio of rise to run is represented in the graph by the steepness of the line and in the equation by the coefficient of x.

text: • Does your graph represent a proportional relationship? Explain why.

content.text: The graph does represent a proportional relationship because it passes through the origin.

text:
The ratio of rise to run is another way to express the pattern of change between the two variables in a linear situation.
  • Is she correct? Explain why.

content.text: Yes, she is correct. The ratio of rise to run describes how much one variable changes if you change the other variable by a specific amount. If the variables are always related in this way, then they have a constant rate of change, which gives a linear relationship.

text: • Does the ratio change if we take two steps at a time? Explain why.

content.text: No, because we’re rising twice as high and running twice as far.  So, the ratio will stay the same.

text: The points (3, 5) and (–2, 10) lie on a line.
• What is the ratio of rise to run of the line?
The ratio of rise to run of the line is (10 – 5)/( –2 – 3)= (10 –5)/(–2 –3) = 5/(–5) = –1
• Find two more points that lie on this line. Explain your method.
For example, (–1,9) is on the line because you can increase the x-coordinate of (–2,10) by 1 and decrease the y-coordinate of (–2,10) by 1.
• Write an equation for this line. How is the ratio of rise to run reflected in the equation?
The ratio of the rise to run is the coefficient of the equation.
To find b, we can use a table:
To find b, we can use the equation and one of the coordinate pairs:
• Does this line represent a proportional relationship? Explain.
This line does not represent a proportional situation because it does not pass through the origin. Also, the values from the table cannot be used to create proportions.
• What is the ratio of rise to run of a horizontal line? A vertical line? Explain your reasoning.

The rate of change of a horizontal line is 0 because there is no “rise” no matter how far you “run.” The rate of change of a vertical line is undefined because there is no “run” no matter how far you “rise.”
How does the steepness of stairs expressed as a ratio relate to a straight-line graph? To the linear rate of change? To a linear equation that represents the graph?

The steepness of stairs is represented by the slope (ratio of the rise to run) of a straight-line graph. The ratio describes how much the line rises or falls for every change of 1 in the independent variable.
The slope ratio is the linear rate of change.
In a linear equation that represents the graph, the steepness of the stairs is represented by the coefficient of x.
Problem 4.1 Preparing for the Walkathon: Using the Ratio of Rise to Run

In the Initial Challenge students investigate the “steepness” of a set of stairs by measuring the rise and run of the stairs and comparing their data to carpenters’ guidelines. The ratio of “rise‐to‐run” informally introduces the concept of slope of a line. In the What If situations students will relate this work to the steepness of lines.
How does the steepness of stairs expressed as a ratio relate to a straight-line graph? To the linear rate of change? To a linear equation that represents the graph?

Remind students that they have explored many patterns of change that involve constant rates. They have explored the ways that the rate affects the steepness of the graph, the coefficient of x in a linear equation, and the rate of change between the variables. Tell students that, in this Problem, they will explore another way to express a constant rate.

Discuss with students the different types of stairs that they have experienced. This can illustrate for students the ways in which changing one or more of the dimensions of a stair can affect its steepness.

• What are the most unusual stairs that you have seen or walked on? What made them unusual?
  • Do you have stairs in your house? Are they like stairs in other houses? How do they compare to stairs in public buildings? Stairs that are outside?
  • How do really steep stairs compare to stairs that are not steep?
  • What does it feel like to walk or run on steep stairs?
  • Do all stairs have the same steepness? How can we determine the steepness?
  • How can you describe the steepness of the stairs?
  • Is the steepness the same between any two consecutive steps?

When the groups have recorded their measures of a staircase in the building, have them organize what they have found out about the ratio of rise to run between several of the steps in the staircase. Ask them to look at the ratios of the rise to the run on the staircases they measured. Have the groups work on the What If Situations.
Listen for how students are talking about the ratio of rise to run. Find examples of conversations where students are connecting their work with steps to the steepness of a line.
Let each group report on stairs they have investigated. Make a class record of the stairs and measures of the stairs that are reported. Compare the ratios for various sets of stairs.

• Are some stairs steeper than others? If so, how can you tell?
  • What is the steepest set of stairs in our list? The least steep set of stairs? How do you know?
  • Can you order the entire list of stairs from least to greatest in terms of steepness?

These questions focus attention on uses of the ratio as a way of characterizing steepness in a mathematical sense. Steer the discussion to measures of rise and run. Make the connection to the Comparing and Scaling Unit, in which the students learned to form ratios as a way to compare situations.

• Is Anna correct in What If Situation B?
  • Does the ratio change if we take two steps at a time? Explain why?
  • In What If Situation C, how did you find the ratio of rise to run of the line with the points (3,5) and (-2,10)?
As you finish the mathematical discussions, have students reflect on the Now What Do You Know question(s).

The method for finding the steepness of stairs suggests a way to find the steepness of a line. A line drawn from the bottom step of a set of stairs to the top step touches each step at one point. The rise and the run of a step are the vertical and the horizontal changes, respectively, between two points on the line.
The steepness of the line is the ratio of rise (vertical change) to run (horizontal change) for this step. We call this ratio the rate of change or slope of the line.

tiles.title: Rise over Run from a line on stairs
Rise over Run on a graph

text: Unlike the steepness of stairs, the rate of change of a line can be negative. To determine the rate of change of a line, we need to consider the direction, or sign, of the vertical and horizontal changes (the slope of a line) from one point to another.
We will learn more about slopes of lines in the Grade 8 unit Thinking with Mathematical Models.
The students did so well in organizing the walkathon that Ms. Chang organized a special field trip to watch a movie.

A movie theatre offers a discounted rate of $4.50 per student to the school. However, at this low price, the movie theatre worries about losing money. The theatre’s operating expenses include $130 for the staff and a film rental fee of $1.25 per student.
• How many students need to attend the movie so that the theater’s income will equal its operating expenses?
The movie company will “break even” if there are 40 students in attendance.
Sample response finding when Expenses equal Income.
We can find when the expenses and incomes are equal.
We can write equations for the movie company’s income I, expenses E, and model profit P as income – expenses. For some number of students n,
The point at which the movie company will “break even” is the point at which their profit equals zero, so we can solve for which value of n makes P=0.
Graph both equations on the same axes. y = 4.50n and y = 130 + 1.25n
Then find where the graphs intersect (using a tracing or some other strategy.) We see that the lines intersect when the number of students is 40.
Find the income made with the price for every student as the number of students increase.
Find the expenses as the number of students increase.
Look for the amount when the income and the expenses are the same ($180). This happens at 40 students.
Students use different strategies to answer the question in the Initial Challenge. Examine each strategy below. Describe how each could be used to answer the question.
On the same set of axes, I graphed the theater’s income and operating expenses for 0 to 50 students.
I wrote an expression that represents the theater’s profit.
Note: Each of these strategies is shown as a possible answer for the IC.
Geraldo’s strategy could be used by filling out the table and looking for the number of students when the income is the same as the expenses.
Anna’s strategy could be used by graphing the line for income and the line for operating expenses and looking for the intersection point.
Sze’s strategy could be used by making his expression into an equation equal to a profit of 0.
Laneshia wanted to find the number of students that make each of the following inequality statements true.
• Find the number of students that makes each inequality statement true.
To find the number of students that will make expenses less than $255, we need to solve the associated equality.
So to make the inequality statement for expenses true, there need to be less than 100 students.

To find the number of students that will make the income greater than $675, we need to solve the associated equality. So 4.50n = 675  n = 150. So to make the inequality statement for income true, there need to be more than 150 students.
• How might this information be helpful in making decisions about the showing of the film?

Student answers will vary. Sample answer: If you only have a fixed amount of money to spend on showing the movie, then the expenses inequality can keep you from going into debt. If you need to raise a certain amount of money from showing the movie, then the income inequality can help you calculate how many tickets to sell.
Examine Jasmine’s Observation. Is she correct? Explain why.

This problem in the Initial Challenge is like the Henri and Emile Race in Problem 2.1 and the Cost of T-shirts in Problem 3.4. I used a graph to solve Problem 2.1 and 3.4. To solve this problem I used a graph. But I know I can also use an equation. I like graphs.
Graphs can be used to find solutions. Sometimes, it is difficult to get an exact coordinate pair on the graph. When that happens, the graph can give an approximate of the solution.
At another theater, they used the equation, P = 3n – 115 to find the profit P for the number of students n that attend the theater.
• What do the numbers 3 and –115 tell you about the relationship between the number of students and the theater’s profit?
The number 3 tells you how much the theater’s profit will increase for each extra student who attends the theater. The number -115 tells you some expense or initial fee for using the theatre.
• What do the numbers 3 and –115 tell you about the pattern of entries that would appear in a table of sample (students, profit) data?

The number 3 tells you how much pattern of change. For every additional student, there is an increase of $3 between consecutive profit entries on the table. The number -115 tells you the profit entry that corresponds with zero students.
• What do the numbers 3 and –115 tell you about graph of the relationship between the number of students and the profit?

The number 3 tells you the rate of change, or slope, of the line (because profit increases by 3 every time the number of students increases by 1). The number -115 tells you the y-intercept of the line.

• Write and solve an equation you can use to find the number of students for which the theater in the Initial Challenge and theater in Situation C make the same profit. Then find the amount of that profit.

The equation for profit for the theater in the initial challenge was P1 = I – E = 4.50n – (130 + 1.25n) = 3.25n – 130. The equation for profit for the theater in this problem is P2 = 3n – 115. If they make the same profit, then we can set the expressions equal and solve for the number of students.
This means that these two theaters will make the same profit for 60 students.
How do the situations in this problem compare to other problems in the unit? In what ways are tables, graphs, equations, and inequalities useful for solving problems?

Student answers will vary. Sample answer: The movie theater situations in this Problem have positive rates of change (like the staircases). Some of the other problems showed decreasing/negative rates of changes. The movie theater problems don’t make sense for fractions of students, but the staircase problems make sense for fraction or decimal measurements. None of the movie theater problems are proportional situations, because none of them would pass through the origin if graphed.

Tables are useful for solving problems because they show several numerical values for a given pattern. Graphs are useful because they give you a sense of the pattern’s behavior over a wide range of values, which is helpful for estimating. Equations are useful because you can use them to calculate any specific value and the coefficients give you information about the problem situation. Inequalities are useful if you are looking for a range of possible answers.

In this Problem students will use what they know about rates, linear relationships, and solving equations to look at situations. Students will draw on their knowledge of different representations to make connections and solidify their understanding of linearity. In the Initial Challenge students will informally encounter systems of linear equations. In the What If Situations students will continue to informally look at systems of linear equations and linear inequalities.
How do the situations in this Problem compare to other Problems in the Unit? In what ways are tables, graphs, equations, and inequalities useful for solving problems?
Tell students that the steepness of the line is the ratio of rise to run, or vertical change to horizontal change, for each step. Tell students that this ratio is called the slope of the line.

• Does the slope change if we take two stairs at a time? Explain.
  • Is the slope the same between any two stairs? Explain.

Pose the challenge of using what they know about slope/rate of change, linearity, and proportionality to investigate some new contexts. Introduce the situation in the Initial Challenge of the field trip to watch a movie after the walkathon.

• What does income mean?
  • What does the term operating expenses mean?
  • What does it mean for income and operating expenses to be equal?

Implementation Note: As students are working on the Initial Challenge they may use the strategies in What If Situation A. If so, push them to looking at the strategies in What If Situation A that they didn’t use and compare their thinking to the other strategies.

• What are the variables in this situation?
  • How do you find profit?
  • What information do you have?
  • Is there a constant rate of change in this situation? If so, what is it?
  • Is there a “starting point”?
  • Which information is about income for the movie company?
  • Which information is about expenses for the movie company?
  • Would a graph be helpful? A table?
  • What do we know about linear situations?
  • How do you find where these ideas are equal on a table/graph/equation?
  • For What If Situation B, what does < mean? (less than) >? (greater than)
  • For What If Situation C, what was the Henri and Emile Race problem about? The Cost of T-Shirts problem?

As you are circulating during the Explore, gather student work that shows the use of tables, graphs, and equations to solve the Initial Challenge. Choose students to talk about their use of these representations to solve problems. Listen for how students are talking about inequalities in What If Situation B and choose students to lead this part of the Summary discussion.

Have groups share how they solved the Initial Challenge. Highlight different representations to help students make connections. Have students share their solutions for the inequalities in What If Situation B. Discuss the use of graphs/equations for the problems in Jasmine’s Observation in What If Situation C. Discuss when the two theater companies make the same profit in What If Situation D.
Teacher Moves: Compare Thinking and Agency, Identity, Ownership

• How did you find how many students need to attend the movie so that the theater’s income will equal its operating expenses? Where do you find the break-even point on the graph?
  • How does using the idea of finding when the expenses equal the income get the same answer as using a graph?
  • How does using a profit equation get the same answer as using a graph or setting the expenses equal to the income?
  • How does using a table get the same answer as using a graph or using the equations?
  • How was the rate of change helpful?
  • How does Geraldo’s Strategy (or if someone in the class made a similar table, use that instead) help to solve the problem? Anna’s? Sze’s?
  • How did you solve What If Situation B?
As you finish the mathematical discussions, have students reflect on the Now What Do You Know question(s).
The following problem provides an opportunity to revisit some of the major ideas in this unit.
The cards contain graphs, equations, contexts that represent various situations, or tables.

• Sort the cards into groups. Each group should represent the same relationships. For example, you may have a graph, context, and a table that “tell the same story” of the relationship between the variables.
  • Explain how each group is the same or different from other groups.
  • Are any of the relationships linear? Explain why. Are any of the linear relationships proportional? Explain why.
A fire in California is burning at a rate of 0.5 square miles per hour. How many square miles have burned after a certain number of hours?
Mia borrows $20 from her uncle to buy a school T-shirt. Mia pays back $3 a week. How much money is left to pay off after a certain number of weeks?
In a trivia game, teams get 1 point for answering the first question correctly. Then for every correct answer, their score doubles.
Will pays $79 a month for unlimited data. What equation would show Will’s cost in a month?

The school is buying tickets, The cost for the first 20 students is $10 per student. The cost for the number of students greater than 20 is $3 per student. What is the total cost for a certain number of students?
You can estimate Fahrenheit from Celsius temperature. Multiply the Celsius temperature by 2 and add 30. What equation will estimate the temperature from one temperature system to the other?
Relationships are included for reference during conversations.
Pattern of Change: As the x-values increase in increments of 1, the y-values decrease by 3.
Pattern of Change: As the x-values increase in increments of 1, the y-values increase by 0.5.
Pattern of Change: As the x-values increase in increments of 1, the y-values double.
Pattern of Change: There are two patterns of change. For x-values of 0-20, the rate of change is 10. For x-values larger than 20, the rate of change is 3.
Pattern of Change: As the x-values increase in increments of 1, the y-values increase by 2.
Pattern of Change: As the x-values increase in increments of 1, the y-values change by 0. (no increase or decrease)
The following representations do not match others. They stand alone.
Equations and relationships are included for reference during conversations.
Pattern of Change: As the x-values increase in increments of 1, the y-values increase by 1.
Pattern of Change: As the x-values increase in increments of 1, the y-values increase by an increasing amount.
Pattern of Change: As the x-values increase in increments of 1, the y-values decrease by 0.5.
Pattern of Change: As the x-values increase in increments of 1, the y-values increase by 3.
Pattern of Change: As the x-values increase in increments of 1, the y-values decrease by 3.
The 3 equations below do not match any other equations. They stand alone.
Students may mistake them for an equivalent equation that goes in the column above each.
If you divide, but do not maintain properties of equality…
If you do not distribute multiplying 2 by both x and –4…
If you add rather than subtract the 2…
<ul><li>Start with any equation, begin to solve the equation and see if it creates any other equations on the cards.

For example, Equation 4 is 2(x – 4) = 16 ➔ (2(x – 4))/2 = 16/2 ➔ x – 4 = 8 this is Equation 7.
  • Pick the “longest of the equations” like 1, 4, or 9 and begin to solve the equation using the properties of equality. Then look for the equations that match the equations you generate while solving.

For example, Equation 1➔subtract 10 from each side and get Equation 13.
  • Begin with the “shortest equations” where we know the value of x, like 2, 5, 6, 8, 10. Substitute the value of x into other equations to see which are true for that value of x.

For example, Equation 2 is x = 4. If I substitute 4 into Equation 3 ➔ 2(4) = 16, it is not true, 2(4) ≠ 16. So, Equation 2 and 3 are not equivalent.
  • Use technology to compare graphs and tables for the equations. The equations that produce the same table and graph are equivalent.
Describe some strategies for recognizing equivalent representations?
Students may begin by finding general sorts and then refine them. General sorts may include:

• increasing linear, decreasing linear, and non-linear.
  • proportional or non-proportional

• determine the y-intercepts and rates of change. Then use those to find the equivalent representation.
  • use one representation to find another. For example, they may put the equations into a graphing calculator to get the graph and table.
  • find the ratio of the rise to the run for the representation. Then, find other representations with the same ratio.
  • Use the properties of equality to find equivalent equations.
  • Look for values that match, for example find an x and y value on the table that is the coordinate pair of a point on the graph. Substitute the values into the equation(s) to see if the equation is true for those values.

This Problem pulls together the main ideas in the Unit. In the Initial Challenge students will look at representing linear relationships with graphs, tables, and equations through a card sort. In the What If Situation students will match equivalent equations.
Describe some strategies for recognizing equivalent representations.
Students have been working with linear situations. They have used tables, graphs, and equations to represent a linear situation.

• Describe some situations from this Unit that we have explored.
  • Are there any clues in the situation that might help us determine that it is linear? If so, what clues indicate the rate of change or y‐intercept?
Describe the card sort in the Initial Challenge. Have students create a poster of their groups of cards to use in a Gallery Walk in the Summary.

• Is there a rate of change suggested on this card?
  • Is there a y-intercept suggested on this card?
  • How do you know if this card is a linear relationship?
  • For this context card, can you draw with your hand a graph to represent the situation?
  • For this table, how do you look for a possible rate of change?
  • What “story” does this graph say to you?

For What If Situation A you may want to suggest to students to draw coins and pouches to help them make sense of the equation. You may want to suggest that they look at “cracking the code” of the coins and pouches to make sense of some equivalent equations.

Collect examples from students on how they determined which cards were equivalent representations. Listen for how they are deciding if a situation is linear. Listen for how they are finding the rate of change and y-intercepts for different representations

Have students display their posters. Use a Gallery Walk for students to see how other students put together their groups. Have students use sticky notes to put questions and comments on other students’ posters.
Discuss the posters from the Gallery Walk that had the most questions.

• How did you decide what to group together in the Initial Challenge?
  • How did you know if a card represented a linear relationship?
  • How did you find a rate of change for a linear card?
  • How did you find the y-intercept for a linear card?
  • How did you find groups for the cards that weren’t linear?
  • How did you decide which equations were equivalent in What If Situation A?
Discuss those equations that were most troublesome for your class.
As you finish the mathematical discussions, have students reflect on the Now What Do You Know question(s).

In this unit we are continuing to explore patterns of change between two variables using linear situations. We use tables, graphs, expressions, equations, and inequalities to represent and these linear patterns and solve problems. At the end of this Investigation,
• What do you know about linear relationships, expressions, equations, and inequalities?

Main idea: In a linear relationship, as the independent variable increases in equal increments, the corresponding dependent variable increases (or decreases) by a consistent amount. Students might describe this as the rate of change. They should realize that this could be zero (as with Leanne) or negative (as with Ms. Chang and Mr. Mamer). They may realize that the rate of change can be measured anywhere on the graph or table. A linear relationship can be represented by the equation y = ax + b. The point where the line crosses the y-axis is b, the y-intercept. The rate of change is represented by a. If b is 0, then the relationship is also proportional. In a linear and proportional relationship, the rate of change is also a unit rate that is the constant of proportionality. Inequalities appeared briefly as a contrast to equality in Problem 1.4.
If a relationship is linear, you can tell if it is proportional in the following ways:
Table: Values from the table are proportional. You can use the values to write proportions or “for every” ratio statements. For example, in the table for Gilberto:
Equation: The amount added into the equation is zero. Or the y-intercept is zero. For example, in the equation for Gilberto:
Graph: The graph of a proportional relationship is passes through the point (0,0). For example, in the graph for Gilberto:
As we worked on the Problems in this Investigation, we used prior mathematical knowledge to make sense of them. We also applied Mathematical Practices to solve the Problems. For example,

At the end of Problem 1.3, Eli’s group noticed that the linear relationship with the greatest positive pattern of change had the steepest line. For example, AGilberto = 2n and AAlana = 5 + 0.5n. The line of Gilberto’s equation is steeper since it has a greater rate of change.
This makes sense since as the number of kilometers increases by one unit, the money each sponsor donates to Gilberto increases by $2. The money each sponsor donates to Alana increases by $0.50.

For Leanne, the equation is ALeanne = 10, so the change is 0. As the number of kilometers increases by one unit, the money each sponsor donates to Leanne does not change. The graph is a horizontal line.
We also noted that the amount of money that Gilberto raises represents a proportional situation. For every kilometer he walks he collects $2. The other two situations are not proportional.

• What mathematical practice(s) did the Eli’s group use to solve this problem?
  • What other mathematical practices did you use to solve problems in this Investigation?
  • In what ways is the mathematics in this problem connected to prior mathematics?
As we worked on the Problems in this Investigation, we used prior mathematical knowledge to make sense of them. We also applied Mathematical Practices to solve the Problems. For example,
What do you know about linear relationships, expressions, equations, and inequalities?

The coefficient a in the equation y = ax + b that represents a linear relationship is the rate of change between the independent variable and the dependent variable. It controls the slant of the line that represents the relationship. Greater absolute values of a mean there is a greater rate of change in the situation, so the lines are steeper. Positive values of a give lines that slant up. Negative values of a give lines that slant down. The value of b gives the y-intercept of the line. It is represented as the point (0, b) on the line or the pair of values in a table. In a table, the y-intercept is the value where the x-value is 0, and the rate of change is the difference in consecutive values of the dependent variable for constant increments in the independent variable.

Any ordered pair (point) that lies on the graph of a linear relationship can be used to find the solution to a problem. The ordered pair (x, y) represents specific values of the variables. If the value of one of the variables is known, then the graph can be traced to find the corresponding value of the other variable. Similarly, any ordered pair in a table for a linear relationship can be used to find the solution to a problem.

To find solutions to inequalities, we can consider the solution to the corresponding equality. Then consider the values that would make sense. Often the situation indicates the values to solve an inequality. For example, we often look at “When is one company less expensive than another company?” or “How many items do we need to sell to make a profit?”

In Problem 2.1, our group looked at how far apart the brothers were after t seconds. For example, at the start of the race, they are 45 meters apart. After 1 second, they are 45 - 1.5 = 43.5 meters apart. After 2 seconds, they are 42 meters apart. After 10 seconds, they are 30 meters apart.

We made a table and found the time it took for Emile to catch up to Henri, or when the distance between them is 0, which is 30 seconds. We used this to choose the length of the race so that Henri wins the race.
A third group member made a graph of the data (time, distance apart), and we saw that it is a line that is decreasing. It started at the y-intercept of 45 meters and crossed the x-axis at 30 seconds.
Another group wrote an equation and then use graphs of the equation to find the answer.

In this unit we are continuing to explore patterns of change between two variables using linear situations. We use tables, graphs, expressions, equations, and inequalities to represent and these linear patterns and solve problems. At the end of this Investigation,
What do you know about linear relationships, expressions, equations, and inequalities?

If you have an equation of the form y = ax + b and you know the value of x or y, you can substitute the value of the variable into the equation. Then, use the properties of equality to solve for the other variable. For example, if y = 3x + 4 and you want to find x when y = 10, then you substitute 10 in place of y: 10 = 3x + 4. Next, you can subtract 4 from both sides to get 6 = 3x. Now, divide both sides by 3 to get x = 2.

For the equation y = 3x + 4, to find the value of x when y = 10, you can graph the equation. Trace along the line to find the point whose y-coordinate is 10 and then read the corresponding x-value, which is 2. To use a table, construct a table of values for the equation either by hand or with graphing technology. Next, locate the pair of values in which y = 10 and find the corresponding x-value, which is 2.

To find the values that satisfy an inequality such as 3x + 4 < 10, you can solve the corresponding equation 3x + 4 = 10. The solution of this equation is x = 2. Then, test values less than and greater than 2 to determine the solution. In this case, x-values less than 2 make the inequality 3x + 4 < 10 true, so the solution is x < 2.

To find the values that satisfy an inequality such as 3x + 4 < 10, you can graph the corresponding linear relationship y = 3x + 4. Then, find the points on the line whose y-values are less than 10. You can also locate the x-values of these points on the x-axis or on a number line.

In Problem 3.2, Equation 1 two equivalent expressions for the number of pouches on the left side of the equation are 4x + 2 and 2(2x + 1). You can use the properties of operations to show that they are equivalent. Applying the Distributive Property to one of the expressions yields the other: 4x + 2 = 2(2x + 1). You can also argue that both of the expressions represent the number of pouches and coins in the picture.

In Problem 3.3, Set 3(a), two equivalent ways of writing the expression on the left side of the equation are 3(x + 1) and 3x + 3. You can tell they are equivalent because the equations 3(x + 1) = 21 and 3x + 3 = 21 have the same solution, even though you would take different steps when solving them. (To solve the first equation, you would divide each side by 3 and then subtract 1 from each side. To solve the second equation, you would subtract 3 from each side and then divide each side by 3. The solution for both equations is x = 6.)

In Problem 3.1, Initial Challenge, for Code 5 Sze’s group first noted that there are 3 pouches and 3 coins on the left and 2 pouches and 12 coins on the left. We subtracted 3 coins from each side. We figured out that the 9 coins on the right equaled 1 pouch.

But then another group showed us their method. They took 2 pouches off each side. This left them a pouch and 3 coins on the left and 12 coins on the right. They could see that if you put 9 coins in a pouch, then both sides are equal.

In this unit we are continuing to explore patterns of change between two variables using linear situations. We use tables, graphs, expressions, equations, and inequalities to represent and these linear patterns and solve problems. At the end of this Investigation,
What do you know about linear relationships, expressions, equations, and inequalities?

Slope describes the steepness of a line. It is the ratio of vertical change to horizontal change. If it is positive, then the line is increasing from left to right. If it is negative, then it is decreasing from left to right. If the slope is zero, the line is horizontal. This is like walking on a flat surface as opposed to up or down a hill.

Finding the slope is the same as finding the rate of change between two variables in a linear relationship. The horizontal distance change between two points is the same as the difference between two corresponding x-values of points in a table. The vertical change in distance is the same as the difference between two corresponding y-values of points in a table.

The Mathematical Reflection provides an opportunity to discuss the goals of the Investigation. Students can pull together their reasoning from the Now What Do You Know questions to summarize their learning over the time.
What do you know about linear relationships, expressions, equations, and inequalities?
Responses to the reflection are informed by the work in the Investigation and thus also reflect:
There are many vocabulary words in Investigation 1. Generating a word bank can help students pull together all of their thoughts for the reflection.

After the class discussion, students can record their responses to the Mathematical Reflection to create a record of their current understandings of the big ideas of the Unit. You may want to keep an Anchor Chart of the conversation so it can be added to at the end of each investigation.
You can gain an understanding of student thinking during a discussion of the reflection question, then assess individual understanding based on each student’s written work.
Having students pull out their notes from the Now What Do You Know from each Problem in the Investigation can help them to synthesize all their ideas around linearity.

Student answers should show they are working to build and connect mathematical understandings for key aspects of linear relationships that are presented in a variety of representations. Students should see that a constant rate of change is a key characteristic of linear relationship and can be identified from a table, graph, equation, or text. This constant rate of change can be positive, negative, or zero. They should see that the y-intercept of a linear relationship can be identified from a graph, table, or equation. Students should see that linear relationships (both proportional and non-proportional) can be represented with words, equations, table, and graphs, and the various representations of linear relationships can be used to compare relationships and to efficiently answer relevant questions for each relationship.
Use the following questions to assess student understanding at the end of the lesson.
